ResponsesInList.Title: Configurable Reports - adding in a filter based on a custom user profile field
ResponsesInList.Text: I have a user profile field with the shortname of 'gender' - this is a Drop down menu, where the options are: Male Female Other Prefer not to say I want to add a gender filter to a report, where the 4 options appear as a drop down in the filter and selecting one then filters by that selection. This feels to me like it should be really easy, but I cannot work out the syntax. How do I do this?

ResponsesInList.Title: Configurable Reports - adding in a filter based on a custom user profile field
ResponsesInList.Text: There are two tables to reference - this was in the help docs... SELECT * FROM prefix_user AS u JOIN prefix_user_info_data AS uid ON uid.userid = u.id JOIN prefix_user_info_field AS uif ON (uid.fieldid = uif.id AND uif.shortname = 'class') WHERE `deleted` = "1" and `institution`="your school name" and `department` = "your department" and `data` = "class level and number"

ResponsesInList.Title: Configurable Reports - adding in a filter based on a custom user profile field
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Emma for replying - I have got the basic report created fine, the bit I am stuck on is adding in the filters that appear to the end user, so they can filter the report. For example, I have managed to successfully add in a date range filter, and the following SQL code will then apply what I need, but I cannot do the same with a custom user profile field filter. WHERE u.deleted = 0 AND cmc.timemodified > %%STARTTIME%% AND cmc.timemodified < %%ENDTIME%%

ResponsesInList.Title: Configurable Reports - adding in a filter based on a custom user profile field
ResponsesInList.Text: Show us your code. And try the %%FILTER_USERS:d.data%% filter ( https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=226805#p1381510 )

ResponsesInList.Title: Configurable Reports - adding in a filter based on a custom user profile field
ResponsesInList.Text: The query is part of a sub query, which is quite complex, but I have simplified it here, to make it more understandable: This basic query will list the times that users have completed activites, and return their name, country, gender and 'age range' (the bigger query is doing counts of these numbers - but that isn't important here). SELECT u.firstname, u.lastname, u.country, uid.data AS "Gender", uid2.data As "AgeRange", cmc.timemodified AS "first_completion_time" FROM prefix_course_modules_completion AS cmc JOIN prefix_course_modules AS cm ON cm.id = cmc.coursemoduleid JOIN prefix_course AS c ON c.id = cm.course JOIN prefix_user AS u ON u.id = cmc.userid JOIN prefix_user_info_data AS uid ON uid.userid = u.id JOIN prefix_user_info_field AS uif ON uid.fieldid = uif.id JOIN prefix_user_info_data AS uid2 ON uid2.userid = u.id JOIN prefix_user_info_field AS uif2 ON uid2.fieldid = uif2.id WHERE u.deleted = 0 AND u.suspended = 0 AND uif.shortname = "gender" AND uif2.shortname = "agerange" ---- If I add the following line to the bottom of the query: AND uid.data = "Female" Then the report will filter to show only people whose gender is 'Female'. What I want to be able to do is to swap that line for something like: AND uid.data = %%FILTER_profile_gender%% so that it picks up whatever has been selected in the 'gender' filter that I have added (this is a dropdown filter pulling the data from the custom user field with shortname = 'gender'. I have managed to get date range filters to work with this approach, but I cannot work out the syntax required for a user profile field. Any help would be really appreciated.

ResponsesInList.Title: Configurable Reports - adding in a filter based on a custom user profile field
ResponsesInList.Text: Is the name of your custom profile filed "gender"? This won't work: AND uid.data = %%FILTER_profile_gender%% Instead it would be like this at the end of your sql query: %%FILTER_USERS: uid.data%% (leave out the "AND uid.data =" part) That should work because you can only filter on one uid.data value, i.e. on one custom profile field. See https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=427857#p1722879 for an example of how it was done there.

ResponsesInList.Title: Configurable Reports - adding in a filter based on a custom user profile field
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Luis - thanks for responding, I managed to eventually end up with the solution that you have suggested, and in doing so, realised that I would only ever be able to apply one such filter at a time, which is a shame as wanted to have 3 such filters in the report, but it looks like that isn't possible.

ResponsesInList.Title: Configurable Reports - adding in a filter based on a custom user profile field
ResponsesInList.Text: Great. Can you share your working code? Being restricted to just one filter is a horrible limitation. Unfortunately, new feature development on this Configurable Reports plugin seems to have have stopped...

ResponsesInList.Title: Configurable Reports - adding in a filter based on a custom user profile field
ResponsesInList.Text: The final working code is as per below, and as you say a real shame that it isn't possible to filter on mor than one custom profile field. SELECT u.firstname, u.lastname, u.country, uid.data AS "Gender", uid2.data As "AgeRange", cmc.timemodified AS "first_completion_time" FROM prefix_course_modules_completion AS cmc JOIN prefix_course_modules AS cm ON cm.id = cmc.coursemoduleid JOIN prefix_course AS c ON c.id = cm.course JOIN prefix_user AS u ON u.id = cmc.userid JOIN prefix_user_info_data AS uid ON uid.userid = u.id JOIN prefix_user_info_field AS uif ON uid.fieldid = uif.id JOIN prefix_user_info_data AS uid2 ON uid2.userid = u.id JOIN prefix_user_info_field AS uif2 ON uid2.fieldid = uif2.id WHERE u.deleted = 0 AND u.suspended = 0 AND u.country = "GB" AND uif.shortname = "gender" AND uif2.shortname = "agerange" %%FILTER_USERS:uid.data%%

ResponsesInList.Title: Configurable Reports - adding in a filter based on a custom user profile field
ResponsesInList.Text: This is a total guess and I haven't tried it! What happens if you try adding two filters, like: %%FILTER_USERS:uid.data%% %%FILTER_USERS:uid2.data%%

ResponsesInList.Title: Display results in source code format
ResponsesInList.Text:
I want to display the report results in the source code format so I can precise URL content. My need is to locate all instances of certain URL file code references across all course activities (that are not the URL Activity tool). I have several successful reports that are designed to search content across books, pages, text areas, etc. My issue is that I cannot see the raw URL in the report results, which instead shows me the produced page content. An example of one of my queries is below. 
```text
SELECT prefix_page.name as PageName, prefix_page.content as PageContent, 
  prefix_course.id as courseID, prefix_course.shortname as CourseName

FROM prefix_page

INNER JOIN prefix_course ON (prefix_course.id = prefix_page.course)

WHERE 1=1 %%FILTER_SEARCHTEXT:prefix_page.content:~%%
```
 Prior to upgrading to 4.5 and TinyMCE, I was able to download a JSON format file which delivered the raw html source, but this workaround does not appear to be working on all content anymore. Plus it was a clunky approach and I am hopeful there is a more simple way to do this! Best case scenario is to be able to download a csv containing the source code so I can pull the url content out directly. Sam

ResponsesInList.Title: Ad-Hoc Contributed Query - Failure query has unenrolled students
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Experts, For a majority of my courses I have been using enrollment method, Cohort Sync. This work well except when I remove a student from a cohort, as cohort's do not record a removal date/timestamp. My Failure query, reports enrolled students without a pass grade. After years of running as expected, two students appeared which were remove from the respective cohorts. Is there something I am missing to only report on students with active enrollments? SELECT DISTINCT CONCAT(prefix_user.firstname, ' ', prefix_user.lastname) AS Employee, email, prefix_grade_items.gradepass AS pointstopass, ROUND(prefix_grade_grades.finalgrade, 0) AS pointsobtained, ROUND(prefix_grade_grades.finalgrade / prefix_grade_items.grademax * 100, 0) AS finalgradepercent, (CASE WHEN ROUND(prefix_grade_grades.finalgrade, 0) >= prefix_grade_items.gradepass THEN 'Passed' ELSE 'Failed' END) AS Status, prefix_course.fullname as course_name, CONCAT('%%WWWROOT%%/course/view.php',CHAR(63),'id=',prefix_course.id) as course_name_link_url FROM prefix_grade_grades INNER JOIN prefix_grade_items ON prefix_grade_grades.itemid = prefix_grade_items.id INNER JOIN prefix_course ON prefix_grade_items.courseid = prefix_course.id INNER JOIN prefix_course_categories ON prefix_course.category = prefix_course_categories.id Kind Regards

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Why would mdl_user.timecreated be 0
ResponsesInList.Text: Strange, but that's an epoch time stamp.   Check servers clock and support of epoch time stamps. Daylight savings? 'SoS', Ken

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Why would mdl_user.timecreated be 0

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Why would mdl_user.timecreated be 0
ResponsesInList.Text: Ask server admin to run this query via command line client: select id,auth,lastname,firstname,email,timecreated,timemodified from mdl_users where timecreated = 0; Just to see if it's not an issue with the query in configurable reports query. 'SoS', Ken

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Why would mdl_user.timecreated be 0

ResponsesInList.Title: Filter for SQL IN() statements
ResponsesInList.Text:
Is it possible to add a Filter to a Configurable Report that does the equivalent of a sql IN(x,y,z) statement? I want to create a sql report that runs a query like this, where the user needs to supply a value in a filter box on the Configurable Report page: 
```text
SELECT


 gg.userid AS
  "Profile id"",


 gi.itemname AS "Exam Name",


 gi.idnumber AS "Exam
  Code",


 c.fullname AS "Course",


 gg.finalgrade AS "Grade"


FROM
  prefix_grade_grades gg


INNER JOIN prefix_grade_items gi ON gg.itemid =
  gi.id


INNER JOIN prefix_course c ON gi.courseid = c.id


WHERE
    gg.userid IN (27793,38223,13454)
```
 I want to have a filter box on the Configurable Report page that allows me to specify a comma-seperated list of gg.userid's that I want to filter the report on instead of hard-coding the csv number list in the sql code. What kind of Filter can I use on the Configurable Reports Filter page to achieve this? I added a: `%%FILTER_SEARCHTEXT:gg.userid:~%%` filter to the query to replace the "WHERE gg.userid IN...", but that doesn't seem to work. Which Configurable Reports filter can simulate a SQL `IN(...)` clause?

Ad-hoc Contributed Reports - does not allow for pre-execution filters - the Where statement would need to be edited to the desired value (course, quiz id, userid, etc.) Ad-Hoc DB queries allows for pre-execution filters.

ResponsesInList.Title: query for average fraction of all the questions in the question bank
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi I was wondering if anyone has a suggestion for the following query: I want to build a report to display the average score of each question in the question bank (these questions are used in separate courses). My main problem seems to be the number of rows in the question_attempt_steps table (over 10 million!) due to the large number of questions (several thousand) and the large number of attempts (more than several thousand ...). As a result, the query I've designed never finishes and keeps running without any results. Is there perhaps a better way of constructing such a query? Thanks for your input. Vincent SELECT `mdl_question`.`id` AS `id`, AVG(`Mdl Question Attempt Steps`.`fraction`) AS `avg` FROM `mdl_question` LEFT JOIN `mdl_question_versions` AS `Mdl Question Versions` ON `mdl_question`.`id` = `Mdl Question Versions`.`questionid` LEFT JOIN `mdl_question_bank_entries` AS `Mdl Question Bank Entries` ON `Mdl Question Versions`.`questionbankentryid` = `Mdl Question Bank Entries`.`id` LEFT JOIN `mdl_question_attempts` AS `Mdl Question Attempts` ON `mdl_question`.`id` = `Mdl Question Attempts`.`questionid` LEFT JOIN `mdl_question_attempt_steps` AS `Mdl Question Attempt Steps` ON `Mdl Question Attempts`.`id` = `Mdl Question Attempt Steps`.`questionattemptid` WHERE `Mdl Question Attempt Steps`.`fraction` IS NOT NULL

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: query for average fraction of all the questions in the question bank
ResponsesInList.Text:
In your query mdl_question_versions and mdl_question_bank_entries are joined but not used in the SELECT, WHERE, or GROUP BY clauses. Do you include them for a reason? Does this do what you want? `SELECT` `q.id AS id,` 
```text
 
    AVG(qas.fraction) AS avg
```
 
```text
FROM mdl_question
    q
```
 
```text
INNER JOIN mdl_question_attempts qa ON q.id =
    qa.questionid
```
 
```text
INNER JOIN mdl_question_attempt_steps qas ON
    qa.id = qas.questionattemptid
```
 
```text
WHERE qas.fraction IS NOT
    NULL
```
 `GROUP BY q.id` 
```text
ORDER BY q.id
    ASC;
```
 Or this: `SELECT` 
```text
  q.id AS
    id,
```
 `AVG(qas.fraction) AS avg` 
```text
FROM
    mdl_question q
```
 
```text
LEFT JOIN mdl_question_versions qv ON q.id =
    qv.questionid
```
 
```text
LEFT JOIN mdl_question_bank_entries qbe ON
    qv.questionbankentryid = qbe.id
```
 
```text
LEFT JOIN
    mdl_question_attempts qa ON q.id = qa.questionid
```
 
```text
LEFT JOIN
    mdl_question_attempt_steps qas ON qa.id =
    qas.questionattemptid
```
 
```text
WHERE qas.fraction IS NOT
    NULL
```
 `GROUP BY q.id` `ORDER BY q.id ASC;`

ResponsesInList.Title: Find questions in course categories
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear community, We have organised almost all of our questions directly into courses. The courses are organised in different categories and sub-(sub)-categories. However, there are very few questions that have been created in course categories due to incorrect permissions, which can be problematic in our case. Due to the large number of categories and courses, a manual search is very time-consuming. I have therefore thought about a DB query ( MariaDB ) via configrable reports plugin. However, my DB knowledge is not so good. Has anyone already carried out such a query and can post the SQL query here? Basically, I just need the ID of the course category in which the questions are located. There is a similar query: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=370896 , maybe that will help as a starting point. The context level would probably be 40 (course category context level), but as I said, my DB knowledge is not so good to find a useful result. many thanks best regards Anton

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Find questions in course categories
ResponsesInList.Text:
Assuming you are using Moodle 4.0 or later 
```text
SELECT *

FROM {question} q
JOIN {question_versions} qv ON qv.questionid = q.id
JOIN {question_bank_entries} qbe ON qbe.id = qv.questionbankentryid
JOIN {question_categories} qc ON qc.id = qbe.questioncategoryid
JOIN {context} ctx ON ctx.id = qc.contextid
JOIN {course_categories} cc ON cc.id = ctx.instanceid AND ctx.contextlevel = 40

WHERE ...
```

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Find questions in course categories
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Tim, that's great, thank you very much. br, Anton

ResponsesInList.Title: Finding every course inactive for more than 2 years
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I'm using configurable_report to extract valuable informations from our platform. I started to learn SQL , but I'm still a big noob, to be honest. I'm trying to make a query to identify every course that hasn't been used by its user since more than 2 years. Right now, I have this : ```text SELECT concat('',c.fullname,'') Cours ``` `FROM prefix_course AS c` ```text JOIN prefix_enrol AS e ON c.id = e.courseid ``` ```text JOIN prefix_user_enrolments AS ue ON e.id = ue.enrolid ``` ```text JOIN prefix_user AS u ON ue.userid = u.id ``` ```text JOIN prefix_user_lastaccess AS ula ON ula.userid = u.id ``` ```text WHERE age(now(),to_timestamp(ula.timeaccess)) > INTERVAL '730 days' ``` `GROUP BY c.id` This query give me every course where you have an user inactive for more than 2 years. I want to find every course where everyone is inactive. And I don't know how to do dit, I probably don't understand how to use JOIN efficientely. Thank you very much.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Finding every course inactive for more than 2 years
ResponsesInList.Text: Why don't you try to get a select of all courses, and then do a Left Excluding JOIN on a select query of all courses in which at least one student has an age LOWER than the interval (not higher). https://www.codeproject.com/Articles/33052/Visual-Representation-of-SQL-Joins This query will return all of the records in the left table (table A) that do not match any records in the right table (table B). This Join is written as follows: SQL SELECT FROM Table_A A LEFT JOIN Table_B B

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Finding every course inactive for more than 2 years
ResponsesInList.Text: AN EXAMPLE SELECT c.id FROM prefix_course AS c LEFT JOIN (SELECT concat('',c.fullname,'') AS courseparticipated FROM prefix_course AS c JOIN prefix_enrol AS e ON c.id = e.courseid JOIN prefix_user_enrolments AS ue ON e.id = ue.enrolid JOIN prefix_user AS u ON ue.userid = u.id JOIN prefix_user_lastaccess AS ula ON ula.userid = u.id WHERE age(now(),to_timestamp(ula.timeaccess)) < INTERVAL '730 days' GROUP BY c.id) withparticipation ON c.id = withparticipation.courseparticipated WHERE withparticipation.courseparticipated IS NULL I didn't test it, but you will be able to make something similar work.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Finding every course inactive for more than 2 years
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks. I tried it but the plugin didn't like it. But I think I see your point, I have to understand better how join works. I'll try again.

ResponsesInList.Title: excessive delay in obtaining the report
ResponsesInList.Text: hello. The report for 6,000 users takes too long to respond and if the same report is made with the adhoc queries plugin to the database it takes much less time. If a direct flat query is made to the database, it also responds instantly. What could be happening? moodle 4.2

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: excessive delay in obtaining the report
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi - We had similar issues. The simple fix is to get more RAM on the server for database operations - Configurable reports have a tendency to hit tipping point where intermediate steps in your query produce virtual tables that are too big to be held in RAM and the result is a sudden massive slowdown. Of course the better solution is to examine your query and work out what is the root cause. Most likely you are starting off joining tables together in a way that produces a huge number of virtual rows, much better to start with a limited table. EG don't join all users onto all course enrolments, start with course enrolments on the course you want and link users in later. If you are using phpmyadmin to run the query on the server directly then you can use "explain sql " to give you a clue where the problem is. Ken (not a database expert, but I have written a lot of configurable reports).

ResponsesInList.Title: Creating a Manager Report
ResponsesInList.Text: We have a course called Enterprise Study Program.  The course is designed to be accessed by A cohort of students (i.e., students from different companies) A manager role (i.e., manager or learning director at each of company), who will be able to access a participation report of people on their team (i.e., from their company) without being able to access the course materials My developer thinks this is not possible.  He said:  "There is no feature that forces a filtering by group in the reports." But I think what we are trying to do is so simple, it must be possible.  Maybe we need to make a copy of the course for each company? How would you advise we proceed

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Creating a Manager Report
ResponsesInList.Text: You should  also be able to achieve this in a single course by enrolling your managers into the course as a NonEditing Teacher (or any role), place them into same Groups as their cohort of students (you would need to first make these groups in the course) and then set the course Settings to force Separate Group Mode. This way, when they access reports or gradebook pages, they should only be able to see their own group of students. This also requires you to check that the role you place the managers in do not have the capability to "access all groups" - more info on the Moodle Doc's Groups page. ( FYI , Moodle Workplace also is perfect for this as it doesn't require you to enroll your Managers into courses with the students, you can make these connections as the site level.)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Configurable reports Custom Variables
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi James, We've done something similar for two custom profile fields we have, "Tenant" and "Organisation" respectively. Below is a snippit that might help (we have a search fields setup to filter the results on a specific date range (for enrolment dates) and the "Organisation", if needed: SELECT DATE_FORMAT(CONVERT_TZ(FROM_UNIXTIME(ue.timecreated), 'UTC', 'Australia/Melbourne'), '%d-%m-%Y') AS EnrolDate, c.shortname, c.fullname, uidt.data as tenant, uido.data as Company, ue.timestart, u.firstname, u.lastname, u.username FROM prefix_enrol AS en JOIN prefix_course AS c ON c.id = en.courseid JOIN prefix_user_enrolments AS ue ON ue.enrolid = en.id JOIN prefix_user AS u ON u.id = ue.userid JOIN prefix_user_info_data AS uidt ON uidt.userid = u.id JOIN prefix_user_info_field AS uift on uift.id = uidt.fieldid and uift.shortname like '%Tenant%' JOIN prefix_user_info_data AS uido ON uido.userid = u.id JOIN prefix_user_info_field AS uifo on uifo.id = uido.fieldid and uifo.shortname like '%Organisation%' WHERE 1 %%FILTER_STARTTIME:ue.timecreated:>%% %%FILTER_ENDTIME:ue.timecreated:<%% %%FILTER_SEARCHTEXT_profile_organisation:uido.data:~%% AND uidt.data like '%PS%' ORDER BY EnrolDate, firstname, shortname We have joined the User_Info_Data and User_Info_Field tables twice because you need a separate instance for each custom profile field.

ResponsesInList.Title: Require feedback on this custom query
ResponsesInList.Text:
The purpose is to get the marks awarded to students for three activities namely pre, post and reflection from some specific courses. Went through the adhoc reports on the internet and customized a query to get the desired results. I would like your feedback on the below query, its correctness and any other feedback. 
```text
    SELECT u.firstname AS 'First' ,
    u.lastname AS 'Last',
    CONCAT(u.firstname, ' ', u.lastname) AS 'Display Name',
    c.fullname AS 'Course',
    cc.name AS 'Category',

    CASE
    WHEN gi.itemtype = 'course'
    THEN CONCAT(c.fullname, ' Course Total')
    ELSE gi.itemname
    END AS 'Item Name',

    ROUND(gg.finalgrade,2) AS Grade,
    DATE_FORMAT(FROM_UNIXTIME(gg.timemodified),'%Y-%m-%d') AS Time, g.name AS Groupname

    FROM prefix_course AS c
    JOIN prefix_context AS ctx ON c.id = ctx.instanceid
    JOIN prefix_role_assignments AS ra ON ra.contextid = ctx.id
    JOIN prefix_groups AS g ON g.courseid = c.id
    JOIN prefix_groups_members AS m ON g.id = m.groupid
    JOIN prefix_user AS u ON u.id = ra.userid AND m.userid = u.id
    JOIN prefix_grade_grades AS gg ON gg.userid = u.id
    JOIN prefix_grade_items AS gi ON gi.id = gg.itemid
    JOIN prefix_course_categories as cc ON cc.id = c.category
    WHERE gi.courseid = c.id AND (c.shortname = 'IDSPPH-CME-FM-22-FHS-MC-PK' OR c.shortname = 'NCD-CME-FM-22-FHS-MC-PK' OR c.shortname = 'RGC-CME-FM-22-FHS-MC-PK' OR c.shortname = 'PAC-CME-FM-22-FHS-MC-PK' OR c.shortname = 'BIN-CME-FM-22-FHS-MC-PK') AND (gi.itemname LIKE '%Pre%' OR gi.itemname LIKE '%Post%' OR gi.itemname LIKE '%Reflection%')
    ORDER BY u.firstname, c.fullname
```
 The sample result is like this: Grade Report with Items 'first' 'last' 'display name' 'Course' 'category' 'item name' 'Grade' 'Time' 'Groupname'

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Create a custom SQL query using the configurable reports
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Khalil, Your query is very complex. Student name: last , First name, Student Email, ID Number, City --> you can get from the table user. To get the course final grade you will need to join to it the table grade_items and grade_grades and course (at least). The total time connected to course is not really doable in my humble point of view. Define Online progress, start date and end date. If it is the start and end date of the course, you have in the course table. If it is the date when the student started the course, then you will need to join the logs table, and God help you with that. If you go in a roundabout way, you could consider start and end date, the completion date of two certain activities , for example. That will require you to join also several more tables. I don't think you can get all this in just one query. I wouldn't try, really. Best,

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Condition in relation to the user field of the report viewer, or how to see only students from a group without SQL code
ResponsesInList.Text: So... if you do it with SQL... You would put conditions like: WHERE c.id LIKE '%%COURSEID%%' -- (so that you would only get results from the course you are at that particular moment when you run the report) AND user.id LIKE '%%USERID%%' -- (where the user ID is the one of the person that is at that moment running the report - the instructor) And you would use these tables at least... prefix_course AS c JOIN prefix_groups AS g ON g.id = fd.groupid -- (I was getting information from forums, that is why I have fd.groupid but you might not need that table ) /*Now remove all the people who are not in the course anymore*/

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Full list of course content - Moodle 3.11
ResponsesInList.Text: I started learning PHP recently, so not fully sure about the above code, but I am wondering how you connect the course with course modules. I can't spot any code that does that. I think using the configurable reports block will be easier, but you probably have another reason to use PHP with SQL. General speaking you need three main tables to do that, the Course table, the course_module table and the activity or resource table to get the course and activity/resources/module details. So in your code above you probably have a reason why you separate the SQL code but they need to be connected to get the right data. I hope that's help Motasem

ResponsesInList.Title: Course total grade in SQL-Report
ResponsesInList.Text: Here is an SQL report I am trying to build. Everything works, except the grade never comes out correctly. What I ideally need, is the percentage of the course total grade. The course is completed, when 95% are reached in the course all together. When the course is completed, the status of "certificate" becomes "valid". So the grade shown in "grade" should be consistent with users having 95% or more having a valid certificate. If less than 95% or no attempt at all, it would have to be < 95%. (If not set or 0, don't show grade).... I got the "gg.finalgrade" column from the ad hoc reports, but the values don't match what is seen in the grade book under "course total" for a user - and they also don't match the validity status in this report. Any idea how to get the correct value like seen here: This is the SQL I have. (There is a way to get that information with a config. reports included report, but embedding those in an SQL report unfortunately does not work..) SELECT c.shortname as "course", u.lastname as "lastname", u.firstname as "firstname", FROM_UNIXTIME(ue.timecreated) as "enrolment date", ( CASE WHEN cmp.timecompleted IS NULL THEN 'invalid' ELSE 'valid' END ) as "certificate", IF(gg.finalgrade > 0, CONCAT(ROUND(gg.finalgrade,2), '%'), '') AS "grade", FROM_UNIXTIME(cmp.timecompleted) as "current completion", ( SELECT GROUP_CONCAT(FROM_UNIXTIME(cc_hist.timecompleted) SEPARATOR ', ') FROM prefix_local_recompletion_cc cc_hist WHERE cc_hist.course = cmp.course AND cc_hist.userid = cmp.userid ) as "archived completions, comma-sep." FROM prefix_user u LEFT JOIN prefix_user_enrolments ue ON u.id = ue.userid LEFT JOIN prefix_course_completions cmp ON cmp.userid = u.id LEFT JOIN prefix_course c ON c.id = cmp.course JOIN prefix_grade_grades AS gg ON gg.userid = u.id JOIN prefix_grade_items AS gi ON gi.id = gg.itemid WHERE cmp.course = %%COURSEID%% AND gi.itemtype = 'course' GROUP BY u.id, cmp.course This is the result, and obviously this can't be right.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course total grade in SQL-Report
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Andreas, First, I think you need to reorder the tables after the FORM, start with the course, then course_compleation, then enrolment, then user then items finally grades, as that will optimist the code. Second, you need to connect grade_grades with the user and items at the same time, like this (JOIN prefix_grade_grades AS gg ON gg.userid = u.id AND gg. itemid = gi.id). I need to say also the above way of connecting the user with the course will show just students who have a record in the completion table, so I think my previous reply will solve part of the problem. However, you still need to find a better approach to connect the user with their courses. The following is another approach for connecting the user with the course. FROM prefix_course_categories AS cat JOIN prefix_course AS mc1 ON mc1.category = cat.id JOIN prefix_context AS context ON context.instanceid = mc1.id JOIN prefix_role_assignments AS mra ON mra.contextid = context.id JOIN prefix_user mu ON mra.userid = mu.id YOu can use subquery if that helps to optimise your code and enhance the query time. I do not think you can retrieve the results in the grade book in SQL code. Many of those calculations happened in the background and were not saved in one table. I hope that will help; please let us know how it that will go with you. Best wishes Mo
role: Picture of Motasem Al Haj Ali

ResponsesInList.Title: How to get the number of student enrolled in groups of each course.
ResponsesInList.Text:
Dear Moodle expert, I would like to inform you that I am using a configurable report and I want to show the number of students enrolled in groups of each course. The following query shows that the number of students enrolled in each course. 
```text
SELECT c.fullname AS 'Course Name'


       ,COUNT(u.username) AS '# of Users'


 FROM prefix_role_assignments AS r


   JOIN prefix_user AS u on r.userid = u.id


   JOIN prefix_role AS rn on r.roleid = rn.id


   JOIN prefix_context AS ctx on r.contextid = ctx.id


   JOIN prefix_course AS c on ctx.instanceid = c.id


 WHERE rn.shortname = 'student'


 GROUP BY c.fullname, rn.shortname
```

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to get the number of student enrolled in groups of each course.
ResponsesInList.Text: I think you need to use 'groups' and 'groups_members' tables to get the name of the group and then the students enrolled on each of those groups. I hope that will help.
role: Picture of Motasem Al Haj Ali

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to get the number of student enrolled in groups of each course.
ResponsesInList.Text: SELECT DISTINCT c.shortname, usr.firstname, usr.lastname, usr.username, usr.email, groups.name FROM prefix_course AS c INNER JOIN prefix_context AS cx ON c.id = cx.instanceid AND cx.contextlevel = '50' INNER JOIN prefix_role_assignments AS ra ON cx.id = ra.contextid INNER JOIN prefix_role AS r ON ra.roleid = r.id INNER JOIN prefix_user AS usr ON ra.userid = usr.id INNER JOIN prefix_groups AS groups ON c.id = groups.courseid INNER JOIN prefix_groups_members AS members ON groups.id = members.groupid WHERE members.userid = usr.id AND r.id = '5' SELECT DISTINCT c.shortname, usr.firstname, usr.lastname, usr.username, usr.email, groups.name FROM prefix_course AS c INNER JOIN prefix_context AS cx ON c.id = cx.instanceid AND cx.contextlevel = '50' INNER JOIN prefix_role_assignments AS ra ON cx.id = ra.contextid INNER JOIN prefix_role AS r ON ra.roleid = r.id INNER JOIN prefix_user AS usr ON ra.userid = usr.id INNER JOIN prefix_groups AS groups ON c.id = groups.courseid INNER JOIN prefix_groups_members AS members ON groups.id = members.groupid WHERE members.userid = usr.id AND r.id = '5' AND c.category IN ("your category id's here") ORDER BY groups.name ORDER BY groups.name From here I download to Excel and make a Pivot report which gives me number of students in each group in each class.

I'm thinking about something like this: 1) At the beginning of the query I would write something like this: constant role_id = 14 2) If I would want to use the constant in a line/staement, I would write: WHERE ra.roleid = role_id Is it possible somehow?

ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, If still looking at a solution for this, you can look at this message . HTH , Séverin

ResponsesInList.Title: Using constants defined in the begining of the query?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I use a lot the configurable reports block, with SQL queries. To allow an easier reading (and updating) of values used in queries, i'd like to be able te define constants at the begining of the report query, that could be used in the query. This would allow modifications, without needing to dig inside the queries, having all elements that could change defined at the beginning. This is possible in pure SQL (with lines like SET), but i've not found any possibility to do that, knowing that a single query is allowed (no ; possible). I see someone asked the same thing (nearly) one year ago, but had no answer. Does anybody have a solution for that? Séverin

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using constants defined in the begining of the query?
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi, For people reading french, you'd better look at the same discussion in french . I've found a solution, using CTE (Common Table Expression) ; this is available since MySql 8.0 (in 2018) or since MariaDB 10.2 (in 2017). You can look at MySQL's help page and MariaDB's help page . So, the application for my use is: at the begining of SQL, i add some lines to define my values at the begining of tables, i had my values table in my query, i use my values table An example, going from this : 
```text
SELECT
  cc.path,cc.name,c.fullname,FROM_UNIXTIME(c.startdate)

FROM prefix_course            AS c
JOIN prefix_course_categories AS cc   ON cc.id   = c.category

WHERE c.shortname LIKE '%law%'        -- To filter courses
  AND cc.path     LIKE "%/1055/1057%" -- To filter category
# AND cc.path     LIKE '%/1055%'      -- To filter category
```
 To this : 
```text
-- Define values to use in query (since 
MySql
 8.0 or 
MariaDB
 10.2)
WITH my AS ( SELECT
  '%law%'        AS Course -- To filter courses
 ,'%/1055/1057%' AS Cat    -- To filter category
#,'%/1055%'      AS Cat    -- To filter category (replace line upper)
)

-- Main query (no need to modify values)
SELECT
  cc.path,cc.name,c.fullname,FROM_UNIXTIME(c.startdate)

FROM my                       -- To be able to use my values
JOIN prefix_course            AS c
JOIN prefix_course_categories AS cc   ON cc.id   = c.category

WHERE c.shortname LIKE my.Course
  AND cc.path     LIKE my.Cat
```
 The main gain is to have personnalised values defined at the beginning of the query , and not inside it. Not visible with thie example, but with big long queries, it's more useful. Séverin

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Category Enrollment by Course Report
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Rob, I think you can try the following. SELECT ### course_categories cat.name AS cat_name, ##course short name with hyper link CONCAT('',mc.shortname,'') as 'Course shortname', CONCAT('',mc.fullname,'') as 'Course fullname', ###Sub query to calculate the total number of students TNr.totalStudentNumber AS 'Nr Registered Students', FROM prefix_course_categories AS cat JOIN prefix_course AS mc ON mc.category = cat.id ###sub query to calculate the total number of students in a course LEFT JOIN (SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT(mu.id)) AS 'totalStudentNumber', mc1.id AS courseid FROM prefix_course_categories AS cat1 JOIN prefix_course AS mc1 ON mc1.category = cat1.id JOIN prefix_context AS context ON context.instanceid = mc1.id JOIN prefix_role_assignments AS mra ON mra.contextid = context.id JOIN prefix_user mu ON mra.userid = mu.id WHERE context.contextlevel = 50 AND mra.roleid= 5 ##you can add here the category path or name## AND cat1.path LIKE '%----%' GROUP BY mc1.id) AS TNr ON TNr.courseid = mc.id #### WHERE ##you can add the category path or name here too## cat.path LIKE '%----%' GROUP BY mc.id ORDER BY mc.shortname Please try it and let me know if that works or if you need further help. Best wishes Mo

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Questionnaire Response across courses
ResponsesInList.Text: I don't use Questionnaire so I don't know its data structure. However, usually a third party plugin has a table with its own name which contains the instances of the plugin in the site and has several other tables which hold user information, files, activity etc. For example, the Feedback module has tables for each item (question) and for each value (response.) But each plugin does this differently. You will have to figure out what the various tables for Questionnaire each do. Perhaps someone here who does use Questionnaire can help you out with the details.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Questionnaire Response across courses
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi JP, I did. So, the responses from the questionnaire plugin are per question type. This means, that each question type for example - radio button, has its own database of responses. Therefore your query needs to select from that database.

ResponsesInList.Title: Group Report
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi there, I want a report which just shows users which are in the same group in a course as the user that is runnig the report. Is this possible? Or at least in the same global group? I've tried using this from another post 
```text
SELECT DISTINCT
course.fullname course,
CONCAT(user.firstname, ' ', user.lastname) AS 'Name',
user.email as 'Email',
user.city as 'City',
user.department as 'Department',
CASE
WHEN completions.timecompleted IS NOT NULL THEN ( FROM_UNIXTIME(completions.timecompleted, '%m-%d-%Y'))
ELSE '-Not Yet Completed-'
END AS 'Completion'



FROM prefix_course_completions AS completions
INNER JOIN prefix_course AS course ON completions.course = course.id AND course.visible = 1
INNER JOIN prefix_context AS cx ON course.id = cx.instanceid AND cx.contextlevel = '50'
INNER JOIN prefix_user AS user ON completions.userid = user.id AND user.deleted = 0 AND user.suspended = 0



INNER JOIN (SELECT vm.userid, vm.groupid, vg.id, vg.courseid, vg.name FROM prefix_groups_members AS vm
			INNER JOIN prefix_groups AS vg ON vg.id=vm.groupid
			INNER JOIN prefix_course AS c2 ON c2.id = vg.courseid
			WHERE vm.userid=%%USERID%%) AS groups ON groups.courseid = course.id



INNER JOIN prefix_groups_members AS members ON groups.id = members.groupid 
WHERE members.userid = user.id
%%FILTER_COURSES:course.id%% 
%%FILTER_USERS:user.department%%



ORDER BY course
```
 but it's not working. Anyone can help me?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Group Report
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes, this is possible.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Group Report
ResponsesInList.Text: Patrick, Basically you looking for one report to extract data about students, where you allow each student when he/she access this report to just see the data about his/her group no more. there is nothing straight a way such as a variable to be used to get you there. But I would like to share with you this example that has been shared by Randy in the ad-hoc contributed reports. If you reconstruct the tables after FROM to identify the group id first based on the userid for the student who explore the report, that would make it easier and you need to notice that in some stage probably you do not need to use the INNER JOIN. For example in Randy's syntax "FROM (SELECT groupid FROM prefix_groups_members WHERE userid = %%USERID%%) AS GRU" in this line we used the variable %%USERID%% to get the user who explore the report, but in this line of code "JOIN prefix_groups g ON g.id = GRU.groupid" we idintified the group id based on the userid that he/she explore the report. Then we joined the other tables that we need to use to get the data from in your case the completion and user tables. If you looking to get this report for the course that this report open in you need also to use the course variable " %%COURSEID%%". Here the list of all the variables and filters that you can use in Config reports block. I hope that's help in some how and thanks for sharing. Regards Mo

ResponsesInList.Title: Course modules (sitewide) within specified period
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi everyone, For a project I'm working on, I was wondering whether it would be possible to amend the following query, as to count the number of different course modules created/added between specified dates (e.g. between 1 Sept 2018 and 30 Aug 2019, etc.): 
```text
SELECT count( cm.id ) AS counter, m.name 


FROM    prefix_course_modules 


AS cm 


JOIN prefix_modules AS m ON cm.module = m.id GROUP BY cm.module 


ORDER BY counter DESC
```
 If so, how would I do that? I found the 'added' column in the course_modules table, so this should be possible.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course modules (sitewide) within specified period
ResponsesInList.Text: Joost, If using MySQL , try something like: WHERE (FROM_UNIXTIME(cm.added) BETWEEN '2018-09-01 00:00:00' AND '2019-08-31 00:00:00') for limiting date ranges. You can do this directly on the numbers too if you want to just use the time stamps and aren't worried about readability later on of the dates

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course modules (sitewide) within specified period
ResponsesInList.Text: Joost and Randy, Also it is possible to add the date columns to your query and then add a filter which make the report as a tool, it can be used for any further query in future. If you are looking to compare that with previous years, I think you need to find a way to figure out the new modules from the old and imported modules. Best wishes Motasem

ResponsesInList.Title: Exporting Reports in CSV UTF-8
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I'm generating reports for a Spanish client and I'm having some difficulties understanding if the reports can be downloaded with a semicolon separator instead of a comma separator. The reports generated, currently, produce an error when imported as CSV or opened as  .xlsx because of inconsistencies between the European and English forms of displaying % and numbers using "," for decimals instead of the English ".". I have the server locale set as es and the database as well. Moodle has been configured to use Unicode / utf-8 as locale as well. ¿Is there something I am missing or there no way of downloading of generating the reports in other formats than en_en comma separated? What I get is: 85.87 or 3.765 but what I need is 85,87 or 3,756 as the European system interprets a , as a decimal. Thank you in advance.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Exporting Reports in CSV UTF-8
ResponsesInList.Text: The formatting of the numbers is handled in your SQL code. You can use any of the various functions like ROUND, CAST, or FORMAT to do that. FORMAT can explicitly take a 'locale' directive too: https://www.mysqltutorial.org/mysql-format-function/ . If you look in your database tables at something with decimals, say, mdl_grade_grades, you will see how it is stored as an decimal type https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/precision-math-decimal-characteristics.html so if you don't format them in any way, you get what the database is storing which for grades will be up to 10 digits, a period, and 5 decimal places. The internal storage of MySQL number types like decimal is standard this way and is not affected by the locale, so you have to do that formatting in your output code.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Exporting Reports in CSV UTF-8
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Randy. Thanks for the feedback. My problem is that I can't use FORMAT because it will mess up the numbers of columns. I'll try to give a more detailed example: Query using Configurable Report returns: |Participation %| Avg. grade| |----------------------|----------------| |57.14 |4.462 | (Using ROUND in both instances) You can see it converts every number to the en_us . separator.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Exporting Reports in CSV UTF-8
ResponsesInList.Text: How are you doing the output? When I use FORMAT with rounding and a locale in place of ROUND, I get the proper formatting both on screen and in the downloaded csv file. FORMAT is implicitly calling ROUND in this case anyway. If you replace the ROUND with FORMAT like this, you don't need any extra column. SELECT id, finalgrade, ROUND(finalgrade,2), FORMAT(finalgrade,2,'es_ES') FROM prefix_grade_grades WHERE finalgrade IS NOT NULL

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Exporting Reports in CSV UTF-8
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you so much, Randy. Thank you for insisting. I'm using Oracle so I had to finally interpret the Format to oracle -speak but it worked. I'm able to download it as csv and the numbers display perfectly in Excel. Thank you once again.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Exporting Reports in CSV UTF-8
ResponsesInList.Text: Thorvaldur, You are most welcome. It's good to know you can get it to work in Oracle too. Randy

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Exporting Reports in CSV UTF-8
ResponsesInList.Text: In the spirit of sharing, if you ever come upon this problem: to_char(round(finalgrade, 2), '999D99', 'NLS_NUMERIC_CHARACTERS = '',.''') What I caused the error was that all the documentation that I found put the . first and then the , in NLS_NUMERIC_CHARACTERS. Reversing them finally extracted all the data and presented it correctly for me to export the report.

ResponsesInList.Title: Site Wide - Count Course Completions
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Experts, I have this handy query - borrowed for the ad-hoc contributions page. Each result is slightly overstated, as it includes my completion - when I launched the course and tested the course behaviors. How do I exclude completions that were done by non-enrolled students? I have tried inserting the %%FILTER_COURSEENROLLEDSTUDENTS%% after the WHERE statement - which results in a query error. Truly puzzled, Shirley SELECT DISTINCT c.fullname AS Course, COUNT(cp.timecompleted) AS Completions FROM prefix_course_completions AS cp JOIN prefix_course AS c ON cp.course = c.id JOIN prefix_user AS u ON cp.userid = u.id WHERE (c.visible = 1) AND (u.deleted = 0) AND (u.suspended = 0) GROUP BY c.id ORDER BY c.fullname

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Site Wide - Count Course Completions
ResponsesInList.Text: You will need to add some logic that checks whether the user is in the course and if so do they have the student role. You could add this logic to the where clause or you could integrate the joins in the main section. There are two main ways to do this: go through the user_enrolments table or go through the role_assignments table. Normally, either will work for students since they will always have both an enrolment and a role assignment. There are examples of both methods over in the ad-hoc reports. Just search for the table names to see some ways to do it. Here's one simple way to do it for role assignments: SELECT u.username, c.shortname FROM prefix_course as c JOIN prefix_context AS ctx ON c.id = ctx.instanceid JOIN prefix_role_assignments AS ra ON ra.contextid = ctx.id JOIN prefix_user AS u ON u.id = ra.userid

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Site Wide - Count Course Completions
ResponsesInList.Text: So I tried this both ways - using the role and using the enrollments as subqueries. It is still a puzzle - With role assignment - I get the same results as if I didn't add the role subquery? SELECT DISTINCT c.fullname AS Course, COUNT(cp.timecompleted) AS Completions FROM prefix_course_completions AS cp JOIN prefix_course AS c ON cp.course = c.id JOIN prefix_user AS u ON cp.userid = u.id WHERE (c.visible = 1) AND (u.deleted = 0) AND (u.suspended = 0) GROUP BY c.id ORDER BY c.fullname IN (SELECT ( ra.userid ) FROM prefix_role_assignments AS ra JOIN prefix_context AS ctx ON ra.contextid = ctx.id WHERE ra.roleid = 5 AND ctx.instanceid = c.id) With Enrollments - I get the same results as if I didn't add the enrollment subquery? SELECT DISTINCT c.fullname AS Course, COUNT(cp.timecompleted) AS Completions FROM prefix_course_completions AS cp JOIN prefix_course AS c ON cp.course = c.id JOIN prefix_user AS u ON cp.userid = u.id WHERE (c.visible = 1) AND (u.deleted = 0) AND (u.suspended = 0) GROUP BY c.id ORDER BY c.fullname ,(SELECT DISTINCT course FROM prefix_course AS c JOIN prefix_enrol AS en ON en.courseid = c.id JOIN prefix_user_enrolments AS ue ON ue.enrolid = en.id WHERE (c.visible = 1) GROUP BY c.id ORDER BY c.fullname)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Site Wide - Count Course Completions
ResponsesInList.Text: In the first one, your IN statement is added to the end and so has no effect: it's just being ignored It needs to go before the GROUP BY and ORDER BY and should be part of the WHERE clause. The second one is similar as the sub-select at the end is also just tacked on. What you are aiming for, based on the fact you only want the results if the user is a Student in the course, would be to think about selecting only those particular USERs. Your first one with the role_assignments is pretty close to what you want to do. Try something like WHERE stuff AND u.id IN (SELECT....only those with role assigment 5 in c.id)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Site Wide - Count Course Completions
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you - I made the suggested changes on both query methods. Neither query had errors but they also produced no results. I need to noodle on on this. Thank you for providing me with useful feedback.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Site Wide - Count Course Completions
ResponsesInList.Text: What's the latest query look like?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Site Wide - Count Course Completions
ResponsesInList.Text: using the enroll logic - Results = 0 SELECT DISTINCT c.fullname AS Course, COUNT(cp.timecompleted) AS Completions FROM prefix_course_completions AS cp JOIN prefix_course AS c ON cp.course = c.id JOIN prefix_user AS u ON cp.userid = u.id IN (SELECT DISTINCT course FROM prefix_course AS c JOIN prefix_enrol AS en ON en.courseid = c.id JOIN prefix_user_enrolments AS ue ON ue.enrolid = en.id WHERE en.id = u.id AND (c.visible = 1) AND (u.deleted = 0) AND (u.suspended = 0) ) ORDER BY c.fullname Using role logic - Results = 0 SELECT DISTINCT c.fullname AS Course, COUNT(cp.timecompleted) AS Completions FROM prefix_course_completions AS cp JOIN prefix_course AS c ON cp.course = c.id JOIN prefix_user AS u ON cp.userid = u.id WHERE (c.visible = 1) AND (u.deleted = 0) AND (u.suspended = 0) IN (SELECT DISTINCT ( ra.userid ) FROM prefix_role_assignments AS ra JOIN prefix_context AS ctx ON ra.contextid = ctx.id WHERE ra.roleid = 5 AND ctx.instanceid = c.id) ORDER BY c.fullname

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Site Wide - Count Course Completions
ResponsesInList.Text: IN is a comparison operator. In both examples, you aren't really comparing anything. So, the second one means WHERE one thing is this AND another thing is that AND yet another thing is that what thing? is IN (that) So, what is the value you are checking for that is IN the selection set? u.id IN(...) would be okay.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Site Wide - Count Course Completions
ResponsesInList.Text: Personally, I would avoid the sub select here anyway. In queries like this I tend to just use JOINs to do it because I know I am not going to be excluding anything. Generally (there's always exceptions I suppose), a JOIN is faster than a sub-select (so they say). SELECT c.fullname AS Course, COUNT(cp.timecompleted) AS Completions FROM prefix_course_completions AS cp JOIN prefix_course AS c ON cp.course = c.id JOIN prefix_user AS u ON cp.userid = u.id JOIN prefix_role_assignments AS ra JOIN prefix_context AS ctx ON ra.contextid = ctx.id AND ctx.instanceid = c.id WHERE c.visible = 1 AND u.deleted = 0 AND u.suspended = 0 AND ra.roleid = 5 GROUP BY c.id ORDER BY c.fullname, u.username

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Site Wide - Count Course Completions
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you - The one thing I have learned, besides I cannot write a decent query, is that using a Join is faster - the sub-select does take much longer to execute. Of course I had is spinning in a loop. Thank you for coaching me through his.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Site Wide - Count Course Completions
ResponsesInList.Text: No problem The real SQL gurus (and gurinis) say as a general rule that JOIN is faster than a sub-selects. It has to do with how the interpreter builds the actual query internally. But sometimes a sub-select or a sub-query is the only way to do things. Or can save a lot of code. And it can be good as a first approximation too. For IN(), I have read that it is basically a shortcut for OR where for example u.id IN(1,2,3) is the same logic as u.id = 1 OR u.id = 2 OR u.id = 3. So u.id IN (SELECT....) is the same as u.id = ORs with all the results of the subquery. Also, in general I find that just checking role_assignments for finding teachers and students is all you need. You don't usually need to also check the enrolments tables. Normal course users will have both but the role_assignments is where the information is stored about which role(s) they have. So unless your query is just counting all the enrollments regardless of the roles, you are going to need role_assignments anyway.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Site Wide - Count Course Completions
ResponsesInList.Text: When I got 0 results - I figured I was asked was missing / excluding the data I wanted - This completely verifies I was clueless -

ResponsesInList.Title: SQL - show data of users that have same custom profile field as logged in user
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I have a question. Is it possible to display data in configurable reports only from users that has same custom profile field as logged in user? For example: There are users that choose custom profile field "accounting" and I also have users that choose custom profile field "taxes". They both complete several same courses. ResponsesInList.Title: Help in tweaking SQL for a Report (Lost)
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all I'm trying to create a custom report (using the Configurable reports block) and I've got a good lot working but I've hit a wall mentally on getting it to do some things and was hoping someone might be able to assist. I need help in doing the following: Display the Grade as a Letter (as set in Moodle) i.e Pass, Fail etc. rather than the numerical value Force the user to select which Month they want to run From Month to Month (so they have the option to either look at ALL of March or Jan to March as an example The date being displayed to be the date they were issued the grade i.e. I did an examination and my course total is populated, the date on the report should be that date the grade was issued. And how to make the report auto pickup the category I am in to run the report ONLY on that category (and thus anything below that point) - if not possible how to prompt the report user to select the category level they want, i.e. be it say Category 1 (and everything within/under) or Category 2 (and everything within and below and so on. What I have thus far: SELECT u.lastname AS "Lastname", u.firstname AS "Firstname", u.idnumber AS "SCC", c.fullname AS "Course", ROUND(gg.finalgrade,2) AS "Grade", DATE_FORMAT(FROM_UNIXTIME(gg.timemodified), '%d %M %Y') AS "Date" FROM prefix_course AS c JOIN prefix_context AS ctx ON c.id = ctx.instanceid JOIN prefix_role_assignments AS ra ON ra.contextid = ctx.id JOIN prefix_user AS u ON u.id = ra.userid JOIN prefix_grade_grades AS gg ON gg.userid = u.id JOIN prefix_grade_items AS gi ON gi.id = gg.itemid WHERE gi.courseid = c.id AND gi.itemtype = 'course' # students only role id is 5 AND ra.roleid = 5 ORDER BY Course, Lastname Jayden

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Help in tweaking SQL for a Report (Lost)
ResponsesInList.Text: If you are using the Moodle default Letters or have changed those in Site admin > Grades > Letters to your own values, you can use a basic CASE statement to show the letters, something like: CASE WHEN gg.finalgrade IS NULL THEN '' WHEN ROUND(gg.finalgrade,2)>=93.00 THEN 'A' WHEN ROUND(gg.finalgrade,2)>=90.00 THEN 'A-' # and so forth

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Help in tweaking SQL for a Report (Lost)
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Randy Thank you so much. I've got the grade letters to appear. New problem, that I don't know if can be sorted or not: The numbers you have used in your post, I take these as a score... rather than a percentage. I tested this by adding a line for a grade that is technically Honors (in our system) with a dummy name and it now shows. Is there a way to make it use percentages rather than a score value, i.e. 100% = Distinction, 90 to 99 = Honors etc? Or is that now falling into the realm of the complex scenario you mentioned? Basically our system is (as set at the Site Admin level for ALL courses/exam activity results: 100 = Distinction 90-99 = Honours 70-89 = Pass 0-69 = no grade the just have to take it again. However, how each course is set is not consistent, i.e. some areas use grades out of 100, others use a set grade system, i.e. out of 20 (but it is not then scaled, its just out of 20). While Moodle can for the most part work out what 70, 90% of things are, I know some areas it doesn't or at least uses score over scale/percentage. The current coding is now: SELECT u.lastname AS "Lastname", u.firstname AS "Firstname", u.idnumber AS "SCC", c.fullname AS "Course", gg.finalgrade AS "Grade", DATE_FORMAT(FROM_UNIXTIME(gg.timemodified), '%d %M %Y') AS "Date Completed", CASE WHEN gg.finalgrade IS NULL THEN '' WHEN ROUND(gg.finalgrade,2)=100.00 THEN 'Distinction' WHEN ROUND(gg.finalgrade,2)>=90.00 THEN 'Honors' WHEN ROUND(gg.finalgrade,2)>=70.00 THEN 'Pass' WHEN ROUND(gg.finalgrade,2)>=19.00 THEN 'TEST' ELSE '-' END AS "Grade" FROM prefix_course AS c JOIN prefix_context AS ctx ON c.id = ctx.instanceid JOIN prefix_role_assignments AS ra ON ra.contextid = ctx.id JOIN prefix_user AS u ON u.id = ra.userid JOIN prefix_grade_grades AS gg ON gg.userid = u.id JOIN prefix_grade_items AS gi ON gi.id = gg.itemid WHERE gi.courseid = c.id AND gi.itemtype = 'course' # students only role id is 5 AND ra.roleid = 5 %%FILTER_STARTTIME:c.startdate:>%% %%FILTER_ENDTIME:c.enddate:<%% ORDER BY Course, Lastname Jayden

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Help in tweaking SQL for a Report (Lost)
ResponsesInList.Text: Moodle always stores the scores as they are (and always up to five decimal places: 00.00000). The percentages you see on the screen are done somewhere in the interface code to make them appear that way, with out without letters. It is calculated on the fly. That means if you want to percentages in your report, you have to do that math yourself in the report.

ResponsesInList.Title: Show me all assignment items requiring grading
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all Desired outcome: A configurable SQL report showing assignment items that require grading ( note we've tried all such supplied reports and none fit the bill ) We only want to see the latest attempt from the student in this report. We have the following query established (we obtained this from the 'submitted SQL reports' on the Moodle site but it didn’t work in the supplied form and required rebuilding) : ```text SELECT asub.id, CONCAT(u.firstname ,' ',u.lastname) AS User, CONCAT('',c.fullname,'') AS Course, ccat.name AS Course_category, CONCAT('',a.name,'') AS Assignment, asub.status, agr.grade, # agr.grader, CONCAT(u.firstname ,' ',u.lastname) AS User, ``` ```text FROM prefix_assign_submission AS asub JOIN prefix_assign AS a ON a.id = asub.assignment JOIN prefix_user AS u ON u.id = asub.userid JOIN prefix_course AS c ON c.id = a.course JOIN prefix_course_categories AS ccat ON ccat.id = c.category  JOIN prefix_course_modules cm ON cm.instance=a.id AND cm.course = a.course AND cm.module = 1 # note: cm.module equalling 1 represents the Assignment module LEFT JOIN prefix_assign_grades agr ON agr.assignment = a.id AND agr.userid = asub.userid ``` ```text WHERE agr.grade IS NULL AND asub.attemptnumber = asub.latest AND (asub.status = "submitted" OR asub.status = "new") # grade is null because there will be no table entry here at all until graded # WHERE 1=1  %%FILTER_CATEGORIES:c.category%% ``` ```text ORDER BY asub.timecreated DESC ``` This produces a result as follows: Our Issue: Records are appearing in the report (e.g. Valerie Christie) stating the status is “submitted”, yet when we view this in the user interface, we see this: The item in the report has a submission date of 25 October (when Valerie originally submitted), and we can see above it has a last modified date of 27 October, when the marker has accessed the submission, found it lacking, and provided feedback to Valerie that more detail is required (hence status of “reopened”). So, given this submission has a status of “reopened”, it should not be appearing in this report whatsoever (the SQL asks only for status=submitted or status=new). Looking at the database for Valerie’s submissions on this particular assignment we begin to understand why we are seeing this record flowing into the report... ...namely, it’s showing the first submission (the first row), yet there’s a later version. We don’t want this! In our SQL, we set the clause asub.attemptnumber = asub.latest to ensure we’re only seeing the latest submission (but it's clearly not working). I do not understand how “attemptnumber” and “latest” are actually working in the system. I would expect the following: attemptnumber latest Additional action: First submission : 0 0 none Second attempt 1 1 First submission record “latest” is updated to 1 Third attempt 2 2 First submission record “latest” is updated to 2 Second submission record “latest” is updated to 2 Can anyone shed some light on the mechanics of this? And we'd really appreciate any advice as to how to best alter our query to get the result we’re after, that is: Only show us assignment items requiring grading Don’t show us items that have been subsequently updated and are not the latest versions Kind Regards Lee Cujes

Basically as coordinator looking to this report you do not want to chase the reopened cases so you do not want to keep the reopened records in this report, but in other hands you still get the same student but different and old record with submitted status. So in the above example for the student with userid = 39170, in the first code you will get just the record with submitted status then when you chase the case you find the teacher already looking after that case or student. If this is right the easiest way to allow reopened cases to appear in your report and order the report by user id, like the following. I think this solution is good especially if you have this report on the course level. In my case I found very little number of reopened records so I think it is no harm to keep this status in the report. WHERE agr.grade IS NULL AND asub.attemptnumber = asub.latest AND (asub.status = "submitted" OR asub.status = "new" OR asub.status = 'reopen') %%FILTER_CATEGORIES:c.category%% ORDER BY u.id IF you are trying to make the report smaller you can restrict the reopened records by timemodified, basically the reopened status records will be created in two situations, first when the student reopen the submission before the due date of the assignment or when the teacher reopen the submission after the assignment duedate. We can drop the first situation by (asub.timemodified> a.duedate) so we will have just reopened records that had been opened by teachers and avoid all reopened records created by the students before the assignment's duedate. ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Lee, First please ignore the previous reply. I hope the following will help. So in the above example for the student with userid = 39170, in the first record you will get just the record with submitted status then when you chase the case you find the teacher already looking after that case or student. WHERE agr.grade IS NULL AND asub.attemptnumber = asub.latest AND (asub.status = "submitted" OR asub.status = "new" OR asub.status = 'reopen') %%FILTER_CATEGORIES:c.category%% ORDER BY u.id IF you are trying to make the report smaller you can restrict the reopened records by timemodified, basically the reopened status records will be created in two situations, first when the student reopen the submission before the due date of the assignment or when the teacher reopen the submission after the assignment duedate. We can drop the first situation by (asub.timemodified> a.duedate) so we will have just reopened records that had been opened by teachers and avoid all reopened records created by the students before the assignment's duedate. To simplify the problem we are looking for "the last record has been create in the assig_submission table AND has no grads" + "excluding the draft status ". I know that you have ( asub.attemptnumber = asub.latest ) but I think the 'reopened' record has been created by the teacher and not the student. Also I think we need to add another condition that the current date greater than due date for the assignment as that will save us to review a lot of cases that still before the due date. MAYBY using IF or CASE statements in the code could help but I am going to show you my code. SELECT asub.id, u.id AS userid, CONCAT(u.firstname ,' ',u.lastname) AS User, CONCAT(' ',c.fullname,' ') AS Course, ccat.name AS Course_category, CONCAT(' ',a.name,' ') AS Assignment, asub.status, agr.grade, # agr.grader, CONCAT(u.firstname ,' ',u.lastname) AS User, #FROM_UNIXTIME(asub.timecreated) AS Submitted, FROM_UNIXTIME(asub.timemodified) AS TIMEMODIEFIED, FROM_UNIXTIME(a.duedate) AS duedate, CURRENT_TIMESTAMP() AS Currentdate FROM prefix_assign_submission AS asub JOIN prefix_assign AS a ON a.id = asub.assignment JOIN prefix_user AS u ON u.id = asub.userid JOIN prefix_course AS c ON c.id = a.course JOIN prefix_course_categories AS ccat ON ccat.id = c.category JOIN prefix_course_modules cm ON cm.instance=a.id AND cm.course = a.course AND cm.module = 1 # note: cm.module equalling 1 represents the Assignment module LEFT JOIN prefix_assign_grades agr ON agr.assignment = a.id AND agr.userid = asub.userid WHERE agr.grade IS NULL AND CURRENT_TIMESTAMP() > a.duedate AND FROM_UNIXTIME(asub.timecreated) LIKE '2022%' AND asub.attemptnumber = asub.latest AND (asub.status = "submitted" OR asub.status = "new" OR (SELECT asub.status = 'reopened' WHERE asub.timemodified > a.duedate)) #AND (u.id= xxx OR u.id= xxx) #AND asub.id =xxx #OR asub.id = xxx #OR asub.id= xxx #AND ccat.name ='xxxxx 2021/2022' # grade is null because there will be no table entry here at all until graded # WHERE 1=1 %%FILTER_CATEGORIES:c.category%% ORDER BY u.id I hope that will help, and looking forward to here from you. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Show me all assignment items requiring grading
ResponsesInList.Text: Lee and Motasem, I've been lurking a bit but wanted to test out some things before I posted. I think this is how the sequence works. 1) The student submits This creates the entry in the submissions table, with status of 'submitted' - but there is no grade table entry created yet (so agr.grade IS NULL). 2) Cron runs The task "Background porcessing for assignments module" runs on the next cron and it creates a new entry in the assign_grades table. It sets the grade to -1.0000 and sets the grader to -1. This is how you know that the assignment has not been graded yet. -1 is not a real user for sure, and probably -1 is not a real grade (but you never know;) 3) The teacher grades it The grader value in assign_grades is set to the grader's user id and then the grade is entered. The submission status stays as 'submitted' the whole time. So, there are two possible conditions for an ungraded submission: it is NULL until an entry is made in the assign_grades table by the cron task, or later it has an entry with a grader of -1 and grade of -1 after the row was created. So, you would want to cover both of those conditions to find all the assignments waiting to be graded. Something like WHERE agr.grade IS NULL OR (agr.grade = -1.0000 AND agr.grader = -1) should cover both cases. Attached is the report xml which I used to do some testing on this so I could follow the path of the submissions. Don't run it in production without adding some where filters to it! since it is written to show you *everything* in the submissions and assign grade tables ;) which is probably a lot of data. So far, I have only tested this out on assignments with one submission. Let me know if that is how you see it working too.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Show me all assignment items requiring grading
ResponsesInList.Text: I'd like to add that I found an interesting bug (that may be a feature?). When the cron task runs and creates the row in the assign_grades table, it set the timecreated to the time that this happens, as normal. However it sets the timemodified to the time that it copies from the submission row in the assign_sumbissions table. Therefore, the timemodified is always EARLIER than the time created for the grades. There may be some obscure reason why this is so; I have not looked into the code. Perhaps it needs to check the time modified date when creating any entry, or for some other purpose to exclude those until graded. But, it is logically impossible for the time modified to be earlier than the timecreated: and in most other cases, for example creating enrolments, Moodle devs do the logical thing and set the timecreated and timemodified to be the same when it creates the entry. But apparently, not for assignment grading. When a grader actually grades the submission, then the assign_grades entry does the proper thing: sets the timemodified to the time of the grading just as we expect. So, the timemodified on ungraded entries is inaccurate and should not be trusted. If you are doing any time comparisons on that, you need to take that problem into account in those cases of ungraded submissions. Only after a real user has graded the submissoin will the timemodified in the assign_grades table be accurate. In the example below, you will see in row four an ungraded entry with a modified time that is three minutes before its creation time. It will stay like this until actually graded.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Show me all assignment items requiring grading

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Show me all assignment items requiring grading
ResponsesInList.Text: Motasem, Ah, I already know the answer to that one: "asub.attemptnumber = asub.latest THIS work some time but it dose not achieve what we expected" ... That is because asub.latest is a boolean where 1 = true and 0 = false. It is not coordinated with the asub / agr attemptnumber and only has those two values. The code always marks the most recent attempt at latest =1 and then immediately marks all the user's previous attempts as 0. That's how it tracks the most recent one. If there is only one attempt allowed, you will always see that the latest =1 and the attemptnumber = 0. When multiple attempts are allowed, then looking for latest =1 that will tell one of the user's attempts the most recent. So, if you want only the most recent submission, then something like WHERE asub.latest=1 is all you need.

For the submission status, I am seeing that a status of 'new' is set in two cases: 1) For the student, it is created the moment they go into the Assignment to start work on the submission. If they do nothing and leave, then the row is still there in the database waiting for them the next time they come back. The status will only turn to 'draft' or 'submitted' when they save it as a draft or actually submit. This will automatically also get a latest =1 as well and therefore any earlier attempts will get latest set to 0. This is how Moodle tracks that the user has started the attempt. It works the same way for single attempts and multiple attempts. 2) When the teacher creates the Assignment, it adds a row to the submission table with a 'new' status. Nothing ever seems to happen to this row at all. It just sits there. Perhaps it is used in some way by the code to set things up, but it does not seem to change at all. So, when dealing with a asub.status of 'new' it matters what role the user has. You can skip all the teacher roles. Also, if you only care about what has been submitted for grading, you can skip both 'new' and 'draft'.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Show me all assignment items requiring grading
ResponsesInList.Text: All submissions are always in the assign_submissions table. Their details will be elsewhere depending on the type they are (online text, file, etc.) and those tables will refer back to the main submissions table. Similar for grading: the grade will be in the assign_grades table, but the details can be elsewhere depending on the grading type, eg scale, marking guide, rubric. I am not sure what your column for "resubmit" does. What matters in the data is the asub.status field and how that is control by whether the assignment has an attemptsreopenmethod and a maxattempts > -1. The key is how many attempts are allowed in the assign setting and if there is more than one, then tracking which one is the current one (asub.latest.). For groups, the assign.tempsubmission and the asub.groupid tell you all you need to know about group submissions: it's just one submission and you have to get the actual members from the group itself. I think - but haven't tested this for sure - that then when the grading is done, it will set the grades individually for each group member. So, in case of a group submission you have to take that into account to align the grades even though there is only one submission.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Show me all assignment items requiring grading
ResponsesInList.Text: If Latest is always = 1, that is normal if all the assignments have only 1 attempt. You will only see  0 if you have assignments with "Additional attempts" set to manual or untilpass and there is actually more than one graded attempt. You will find the status of 'new' in a couple of cases: when the teacher (or manager or whoever) first creates a new assignment, it always puts an entry in there with a status of 'new' - I don't know why it does this, but it never changes and you can ignore it for real submissions from students. I have also seen a status of 'new' then the student is actually working on the assignment: it creates the 'new' entry and it stays that way until the student either 1) saves it as a 'draft' (if the settings allow that) or 2) they submit it. So, the roles matter if you are looking only for the student ones. I see admins in mine all the time when I am testing as an admin: it just records the user id of whoever makes the new assignment. It may not be the teacher at all. Usually I don't bother with adding all the roles checking: I just ignore a status of 'new'. Teachers will never have a submission status of 'submitted' since they don't have permission to submit (by default anyway.)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Show me all assignment items requiring grading
ResponsesInList.Text: To me, the heart of the matter is: FROM prefix_assign_submission asub LEFT JOIN prefix_assign_grades ag ON ag.assignment = asub.assignment AND ag.userid = asub.userid AND ag.attemptnumber = asub.attemptnumber WHERE asub.status = 'submitted' AND (ag.grader = -1 OR ag.grader IS NULL) If the user can't submit, no matter their role, it will not be here. By default only the Student role has mod/assign:submit allowed. If you have admins and managers enrolling themselves as students in courses, then, Moodle can't help you much since they are properly enrolled. (Maybe put those people in a cohort and then exclude those cohort members from the query in your where clause?). I have never seen a grade for a 'new' status other than -1 with a grader of -1. You can't grade a 'new' status anyway. Also, 'reopened' status is used when "Additional attempts" is set to manual or until pass. The additional attempts get the 'reopened' status after the teacher has allowed a new attempt or if using until pass then the assignment did not get the passing grade. In either case, a new submission entry is made with the 'reopened' status. This marks a new, additional attempt and it will have the 'reopened' status until the student actually makes a submission. If you aren't using "Additional attempts" you won't see it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Show me all assignment items requiring grading
ResponsesInList.Text: By the way, here is how group submissions work. The asub.userid is 0 and then the groupid column holds the id of the group. It doesn't record the id of the user who does the actual submission on behalf of the group (maybe in the logs it does, but not in the submission table).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to apply filter based on custom profile field
ResponsesInList.Text: Sarath, The help for that fields in not very clear. You need to do the following: 1) In your code, you must add a identifier to your filter like this FILTER_SEARCHTEXT_ID1 where ID1 is just any arbitrary identifier you want. I usually just use _1 or _2 but you could use _username or to make it clearer just _U. There must be an underscore. So, %%FILTER_SEARCHTEXT_U:user2.username:~%% will work for you. 2) In the filter tab for the ID, add ONLY the identifier part without the underscore line, so 1 or 2 or U or whatever you use. This method allows you to have two filters to search with, so: %%FILTER_SEARCHTEXT_U:user2.username:~%% %%FILTER_SEARCHTEXT_F:user2.firstname:~%% then you would have two filters with IDs of U and F and Labels of "Username" and "Firstname" Etc.

(See my explanation of how this works now here: https://docs.moodle.org/311/en/ad-hoc_contributed_reports#Using_the_Search_Text_filter ). Eg for the fourth one, this is the proper syntax for the latest CR : WHERE gi.itemname LIKE '%extra credit%' AND gi.gradetype = '1' AND gi.hidden = '0' AND gi.aggregationcoef = '0' AND c.visible = 1 AND (SELECT COUNT( ra.userid ) FROM prefix_role_assignments AS ra JOIN prefix_context AS ctx ON ra.contextid = ctx.id WHERE ra.roleid = 5 AND ctx.instanceid = c.id) > 0 %%FILTER_SEARCHTEXT_C:c.idnumber:~%% GROUP BY Course_ID, gi.id ORDER BY StartDate, Course_ID Where in the Filters definitions you have a Search Text filter with an ID Number set to "C".
