We're also pulling Submissions and Grades into our central SRS via Web Services, and the submissions are coming in via that route, leading me to wonder if some fields relating to Grades/Assignment Submissions only populate once they've been viewed by a user with grading permissions? I doubt it, but I'm at a loss as to why the query misses some records. The query is: ```text SELECT DISTINCT ``` ```text g.name AS "Group", ``` ```text u.firstname AS "First", ``` ```text u.lastname AS "Last", ``` ```text c.fullname AS "Course", ``` ```text a.name AS "Assignment", ``` ```text sub.status AS "Status", ``` ```text DATE_FORMAT(FROM_UNIXTIME(sub.timemodified), '%d/%m/%Y (%H:%i)') AS "When", ``` ```text cm.module, ``` ```text concat('Provide Feedback (Filterable View)  | Provide Feedback (Simplified View)') ``` ```text AS "Feedback Status" ``` ```text FROM prefix_assign_submission sub ``` ```text JOIN prefix_assign a ON a.id = sub.assignment AND a.name NOT LIKE '%Summative%' ``` ```text JOIN prefix_user u ON u.id = sub.userid ``` ```text JOIN prefix_course c ON c.id = a.course ``` ```text JOIN prefix_groups g ON g.courseid=c.id ``` ```text JOIN prefix_groups_members gm ON u.id=gm.userid and gm.groupid=g.id ``` ```text JOIN prefix_course_modules cm ON c.id = cm.course ``` ```text JOIN prefix_modules m ON m.id=cm.module ``` ```text JOIN prefix_context cxt ON c.id=cxt.instanceid AND cxt.contextlevel=50 ``` ```text JOIN prefix_role_assignments ra ON cxt.id = ra.contextid AND ra.roleid=5 AND ra.userid=u.id ``` ```text JOIN prefix_assign_grades ag ON sub.userid = ag.userid AND sub.assignment = ag.assignment ``` ```text ``` ```text WHERE cm.instance = a.id AND cm.module = 1 AND sub.status != "new" AND g.name NOT LIKE 'BA%' AND ag.grade < 1.0 AND ``` ```text LOWER(g.name) LIKE LOWER((CONCAT ('%', ``` ```text ( ``` ```text     SELECT CONCAT(firstname,lastname) ``` ```text     FROM prefix_user usr ``` ```text     WHERE usr.id = %%USERID%% ``` ```text ), '%'))) ``` ```text ORDER BY c.fullname, a.name, u.lastname ``` Many thanks for any pointers. All the best, Paul

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Missing rows in Report
ResponsesInList.Text: Paul I would look at a couple of things: - You are doing an inner join on assign_grades but there can be submission not yet graded. I would experiment with an outer join of some sort, left join probably, to see if those get included when submitted and not yet graded.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Missing rows in Report
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Randy, I'll try what you suggest and get back to you with the results. All the best Paul

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Missing rows in Report
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Randy, Just to update; using a Left join on the context and assign_grades tables made the difference. There was also the ag.grade < 1.0 condition which excluded the same missing items  - the starting grade of 1.0 or -1.0 sometimes only gets recorded to the assign_grades table once the submission grading page is visited, for a reason I haven't yet fathomed, which confused things a little. Many thanks for your help with this! 👍

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Missing rows in Report
ResponsesInList.Text: Paul, Nice: Left Join for the win. Also, I hear you about the assign_grades table: I have yet to fully figure out when it puts entries in there. It seems inconsistent, especially if you start looking at the time stamps for those. I suspect cron is involved, but I am not sure. I have seen rows in that table with no grader (-1) or grade (also -1) with no real submissions at all yet but sometimes no rows at all until a submission has been actually graded. It's a mystery I haven't fully looked into yet.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Create a report for the whole of system (all courses)
ResponsesInList.Text: You can check the queries on the Ad-hoc contributed queries page that may help you. For example, this query shows all Assignments waiting to be graded . There are a number of queries there relating to Quizzes as well. To get ALL activities waiting to be graded, you have to go through each type of activity separately since each activity that can be graded has a completely different way of storing that data. Assignments and Quizzes and Forums all do it in a different way. So, you really have to have three (or more) reports and put them together to get total coverage.

ResponsesInList.Title: Length limit - concat and group_concat
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, I would like to create a query: From each teacher I want to show all his courses with the urls of the courses. If I query  the course name or ID for the courses, there is a difference of the result. As soon as I use Group_Concat or concat not all courses are displayed. Are there any restrictions on the number of characters here? SELECT concat (u.firstname, " ", u.lastname) as trainer, GROUP_CONCAT(c.fullname, ' </br>') as course,  # incomplete list of courses GROUP_CONCAT(c.id, ' </br>') as course2,      # complete list of course-ids u.auth FROM prefix_course AS c JOIN prefix_context AS ctx ON c.id = ctx.instanceid JOIN prefix_role_assignments AS ra ON ra.contextid = ctx.id and ra.roleid= 3 JOIN prefix_user AS u ON u.id = ra.userid Group BY u.id

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Length limit - concat and group_concat
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes, there is a restriction. The default length is 1024. Official documentation and how to up that are here: https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/aggregate-functions.html#function_group-concat as well as some other ways of doing it in the accepted answer to this post: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/12001919/mysql-truncates-concatenated-result-of-a-group-concat-function

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Length limit - concat and group_concat
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for the quick reply and the helpful links!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Length limit - concat and group_concat
ResponsesInList.Text: No worries. I ran into this exact issue myself about a year ago and the solution was to up the number in the mysql .ini file.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Activity completion including COHORT
ResponsesInList.Text: I would suggest that you step back and first do something basic then. - Get a handle on the basics of query syntax from some of the learning sites, like https://www.w3schools.com/mysql/ and https://www.mysqltutorial.org/ . You only need to be sure of the basics first (like how SELECT, JOIN, and WHERE work) to do about many if not most of the queries on that page. - Start with a basic query and add to it: even experienced users do it this way rather than try to cram two complex queries together. As John Gall says, "All complex systems that work can be shown to come from simpler systems that work." - Study some queries that are similar to what you need if not exact and get those running first: do those above queries on completion and the ones on groups run and work on your site? If not, then combining won't either.

Understanding all these Adhoq queries and why they are built the way they are is key as well.  Otherwise you'll never know what can be cut out.  Each site and need is often quite different.

ResponsesInList.Title: Users Report - "Logins in the platform"?
ResponsesInList.Text: I have created a users report with the following: The Users Statistics column is using "Logins in the platform" The User profile field named "Last Login" is using "Current login" The last login date seems to be working fine. However I am seeing many results with users with a "current login" date, but a 0 for "Logins in the platform" Am I misunderstanding something about these two columns?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Users Report - "Logins in the platform"?
ResponsesInList.Text: "Current login" actually means the most recent login, whenever that may have been, if ever. "Last login" means the one before that, if one. So, it is the last two logins, if any. The value will be 0 if the there was no login. You can see this for yourself if you do a simple query to compare the dates: SELECT u.username, DATE_FORMAT(FROM_UNIXTIME(u.currentlogin),'%Y-%m-%d %H:%i') AS "Current Login", DATE_FORMAT(FROM_UNIXTIME(u.lastlogin),'%Y-%m-%d %H:%i') AS "Last login" FROM prefix_user u

ResponsesInList.Title: Adding Feedback Files to an Assignment Grades report
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I'm hoping someone with better SQL skills than I can help me with this (previoulsy posted this to the dev community - I forgot there's this specific CR forum!) We're wanting to download the Feedback File a tutor provides for a student for each assignment into our central SIS or at least for now just make it available via Configurable reports, but I'm struggling to create a relationship between the tutor's feedback file and the grade item for the student which the file was uploaded for. It's complicated a little by us having multiple tutors within each course with their own private student groups, so not all feedback in a course belongs to one tutor, although I'm hoping there's a way of matching a feedback file against the tutor who uploaded it/graded the student. We have a separate report that lists links to a student's assignment submission (which contains the report file) against the marking tutor, but we need to be bringing the report files into the same report as the grades. Many thanks, Paul

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding Feedback Files to an Assignment Grades report
ResponsesInList.Text: Just to update, this is the query I have to-date: ```text SELECT ag.userid, ag.grader, u.username AS 'Graded by', ag.id AS "ag.id", ag.assignment AS "ag.assignment", f.itemid, f.contextid AS 'f.contextid', ctx.instanceid AS "ctx.instanceid", concat('',f.filename,'')  AS "Feedback File", DATE_FORMAT(FROM_UNIXTIME(f.timecreated),'%Y-%m-%d %H:%i') AS "Created" FROM prefix_files f JOIN prefix_user u ON u.id = f.userid JOIN prefix_context ctx ON f.contextid = ctx.id JOIN prefix_assign a ON ctx.instanceid = a.id JOIN prefix_assign_grades ag ON a.id = ag.assignment AND ag.grader = f.userid WHERE f.component = 'assignfeedback_file' AND  f.filearea = 'feedback_files' AND  f.filesize > 0 ORDER BY u.username, f.filename ``` So although I have the feedback file(s) associated with the grader, I'm yet to work out how to associate the feedback file with the grade or assignment submission. The tables I've checked so far have yielded no common fields between these two halves of the problem.  Hoping somebody can help with this? Many thanks, Paul

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding Feedback Files to an Assignment Grades report
ResponsesInList.Text: When the .component in the _files table is of type 'assignfeedback_file' then the .itemid there is the id of the grade in the _assign_grades table. The feedback file and the grade go together. Or f.itemid = ag.id WHERE f.component = 'assignfeedback_file'.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding Feedback Files to an Assignment Grades report
ResponsesInList.Text: Many thanks Randy! Looking back I'd already tried that but had another Join interfering with the results, you've saved me a lot of time there!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding Feedback Files to an Assignment Grades report
ResponsesInList.Text: Most welcome, Paul.

SELECT u.username As 'User', c.shortname AS 'Course', m.name AS Activitytype, CASE WHEN m.name = 'quiz'  THEN (SELECT name FROM prefix_quiz WHERE id = cm.instance) END AS Activityname, CASE WHEN cm.completion = 0 THEN '0 None' END AS Activtycompletiontype, CASE WHEN cm.instance = 0 THEN 'In Progress' END AS 'Progress',

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Global - Quiz Attempts that are in progress - Abandoned Attempts
ResponsesInList.Text: Shirley, This looks like it is trying to take the long way around and not getting there. There is a table just for quiz attempts with their status, but that in not in the query. A query that starts with something like SELECT * FROM prefix_quiz_attempts WHERE state = 'inprogress' or perhaps WHERE state != 'finished' (since the status options are: finished, overdue, inprogress, abandoned) would be the key part I would think. Then you can easily join the user and quiz tables from the quiz_attempts columns. The timefinish should also be 0 if attempt was not finished so in that case timemodified was the last time they answered a question.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Global - Quiz Attempts that are in progress - Abandoned Attempts

ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Experts, I have been updating and testing my query against my expected results, but I still cannot seem to exclude students who were unenrolled. The student has moved to a new job assignment and no longer is required to take the course. The enrollment was removed, but somehow the query is still "correctly" reporting that the student has an abandoned attempt. Correct, but not really what I intended. How do I exclude student who are no longer enrolled? SELECT CONCAT(u.firstname, ' ', u.lastname) AS Employee, c.fullname, state, timefinish FROM prefix_quiz_attempts as qa JOIN prefix_user u ON qa.userid = u.id JOIN prefix_quiz AS q ON q.id = qa.quiz INNER JOIN prefix_course c ON q.course = c.id INNER JOIN prefix_enrol en ON en.courseid = c.id WHERE state = 'abandoned' and timefinish = 0 AND u.deleted = 0 AND u.suspended = 0 AND (c.visible =1) %%FILTER_COURSEENROLLEDSTUDENTS%%

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Global - Quiz Attempts that are in progress - Abandoned Attempts
ResponsesInList.Text: Shirley, Probably the easiest way - that is the way of least disruption to the existing query - is to add and AND clause to the WHERE which would be a sub-select statement that limits the results to only students enrolled in the course. You already have the user and course, you just need to check for the enrollment exists. There's a number of examples with code you can borrow over the the contributed page, e.g. https://docs.moodle.org/311/en/ad-hoc_contributed_reports#Students_in_all_courses_of_some_institute

ResponsesInList.Title: Survey results - SQL syntax error for MariaDB for setting limit offset
ResponsesInList.Text:
```text

```
 Hi everyone, this query works to get survey module results massively. You can use it! 😀

But there is a little problem with the syntax when trying to set a specific limit:

- I already have set max 20,000 rows in the plugin configuration: block_configurable_reports | reportlimit.
- As the result is bigger than 20,000, I want to set a row limit setting a offset, everytime until get all the information I want
- (LIMIT 0, 20,000)
- (LIMIT 20,000, 40,000)
- (LIMIT 40,000, 80,000)

- But the plugin send me this error message: "You have an error in your SQL syntax; check the manual that corresponds to your MariaDB server version for the right syntax to use near 'LIMIT 0, 20000' at line 41"

Please, help! Is this a plugin limitation, because there is already set a limit by default by report limit parameter?
Is there another option?

This is the query:
-----
select distinct
f.name as 'Encuesta',
c.fullname as 'Curso',
c.shortname as 'Nombre Corto de Curso',
c.id as 'Curso ID',
(
select concat(d.firstname, ' ', d.lastname)
from prefix_role_assignments mra
inner join prefix_user d on mra.userid = d.id
inner join prefix_context context on mra.contextid = context.id
where
context.instanceid = c.id and
mra.roleid in (select id from prefix_role where shortname like '%teacher%')
GROUP BY d.id
limit 1
) as 'Docente',
(
select d.idnumber
from prefix_role_assignments mra
inner join prefix_user d on mra.userid = d.id
inner join prefix_context context on mra.contextid = context.id
where
context.instanceid = c.id and
mra.roleid in (select id from prefix_role where shortname like '%teacher%')
GROUP BY d.id
limit 1
) as 'Docente ID',
concat(u.firstname, ' ', u.lastname) as 'Usuario',
u.idnumber as 'Usuario ID',
date_format(from_unixtime(fc.timemodified), '%e %b %Y %H:%i:%s') as 'Fecha y Hora de Respuesta',
fi.name as 'Pregunta',
fv.value as 'Respuesta'
from prefix_feedback_completed fc
inner join prefix_feedback f on fc.feedback = f.id
inner join prefix_course c on f.course = c.id
inner join prefix_user u on fc.userid = u.id
inner join prefix_feedback_item fi on f.id = fi.feedback
inner join prefix_feedback_value fv on fi.id = fv.item and fv.completed = fc.id
where f.name = 'Encuesta sobre desempeño docente'
order by c.id
limit 0, 20000
----

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Survey results - SQL syntax error for MariaDB for setting limit offset
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, If i'm not wrong, the plugin enforces the limit, so you can't specify one in your query. It could be cool to have a way to specify a limit in the query (ticking a checkbox, or automatically if a LIMIT line is in the query), but the enforced limit is here to avoid problems with too much results (and having a way to specify another limit could break this protection). Séverin

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Survey results - SQL syntax error for MariaDB for setting limit offset
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Mr. Terrier: It looks like you said. Thank you for your time. Its very kind of you.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle 3.11 Compatibility?
ResponsesInList.Text: A 500 server error could mean many things, like the results of a query are huge, or there are caching issues, or server configuration, or internal network issues, or database connection issues, or a myriad of other things. It's a generic error from Apache (or whatever web server). Config Reports does not set any cookie. The only cookie it needs is the standard Moodle session cookie. Can you run a simple one line report like SELECT * FROM prefix_user WHERE id = 2 ? If so, it's something to do with timing or performance or the query, as Emma suggests. But no reports at all, even the simplest, can run, then it is something else. If it was working before and now it is not, something changed. That's not so helpful, I know, but if it was working and now it is not.... something somewhere is different.

ResponsesInList.Text: Hi ! I am using Moodle 3.4 and Configurable Reports 3.1.1 I need to run a Store Procedure. But Configurable reports adds at the end "limit 5000", so it doesnt work with that limit.... Do you know how i can avoid that limit?
role: Picture of Luis Guillermo Loaiza Cordero

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Query no limit for run Store Procedure
ResponsesInList.Text: Be very careful with this - Site administration>Plugins>reports Ad-hoc database queries.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Query no limit for run Store Procedure
ResponsesInList.Text: If you mean you need to increase the limit, you can do that in Site admin > Plugins > Blocks > Configurable reports > Report row limit. The default is 5,000. You can increase (or decrease) that to what you need. This is a global setting that affects all reports, so if you do have a lot of large reports users are running, it could slow things down. If you mean you need to remove the appending of the LIMIT parameter for the stored procedure to work when the plugin code builds the SQL query, then you would need to edit the code for the plugin where that limit is appended. Take a look in the block's directory /reports/sql/report_class.php to do that.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: view the badges in a course (issued AND not issued) for all users
ResponsesInList.Text: Without going into too much detail, usually the issue with using groups like this is the inner join: so when you do that, it limits all the badges shown in the results to only those with groups, that is in this case when awarded. This is a case where a left join is probably a way to a solution.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: view the badges in a course (issued AND not issued) for all users
ResponsesInList.Text: Lawrence, I would not begin with that query. If you need to see all the badges, issued or not, I would begin with a query that shows all badges, such as this one . The query above starts with only awarded badges, as you can see in the FROM statement that it starts with the badge_issued table and then goes from there. So, it already excludes badges that don't yet have any users earning them. So, I would instead start with a query showing me all the badges in a courses, then add in the details for those that have been awarded. All the important pieces that you need are in two those queries, I would just do them the other way around, so to speak.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: view the badges in a course (issued AND not issued) for all users
ResponsesInList.Text:
Off the top of my head, here is a short query that does that: it is only the basics with no error checking or anything but shows you the structure: start with all badges, then pull the issued ones. Type = 2 means only course badges are included. SELECT c.shortname "Course", b.name AS "Badge", u.username FROM prefix_badge b JOIN prefix_course c ON c.id = b.courseid LEFT JOIN prefix_badge_issued bi ON b.id = bi.badgeid LEFT JOIN prefix_user u ON bi.userid = u.id WHERE b.type = 2 # AND c.id = some course id number(s) or use %%COURSEID%% if using Config Reports 
```text

```

I've tried experimenting with conditional arguments to target these but I've only managed to separate badges issued from badges not issued into different columns. Am I going completely up the wrong tree? SELECT u.username, b.name, CASE WHEN NOT EXISTS (SELECT * FROM prefix_badge_issued AS bi WHERE bi.userid = u.id) THEN u.username Else '*' END AS "users_without_badge" FROM prefix_badge AS b JOIN prefix_course AS c ON c.id = b.courseid LEFT JOIN prefix_badge_issued AS bi ON b.id = bi.badgeid LEFT JOIN prefix_user AS u ON bi.userid = u.id WHERE c.id = 961 thanks

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: view the badges in a course (issued AND not issued) for all users
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes, it shows nulls since the data is null, but you can easily add something else with code like IF(u.username IS NULL,'-',u.username). In any case, the sorting is what matters. If you only want to find the badges with no awards, then this will help you out: SELECT b.name FROM prefix_badge b LEFT JOIN prefix_badge_issued bi ON b.id = bi.badgeid WHERE bi.badgeid IS NULL Again, the outer join makes this possible. However, if you are thinking of trying to get all this into two columns (awarded vs unawarded) that would be very difficult in SQL , easy in PHP. Personally, I would use the first report and just sort it properly or download it into a spreadsheet to do any further machinations with it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Question re SQL selecting question bank category and subcategory names
ResponsesInList.Text: In your query when you defined your columns you used the same select statement for the Category and the Lesson, cat.name. You need to change one of the select statements for either the Category or Lesson. Kind Regards

ResponsesInList.Title: Only need Failed Results
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Query Experts, I have a working query, that was heavily borrowed from a Moodle expert. The results look like this, with passing and failed results - but I need to limit the results to just Failed values. How do I modify this query, to only receive a status of failed? SELECT prefix_user.firstname, prefix_user.lastname, prefix_user.email, prefix_grade_items.gradepass AS pointstopass, ROUND(prefix_grade_grades.finalgrade, 0) AS pointsobtained, ROUND(prefix_grade_grades.finalgrade / prefix_grade_items.grademax * 100, 0) AS finalgradepercent, (CASE WHEN ROUND(prefix_grade_grades.finalgrade, 0) >= prefix_grade_items.gradepass THEN 'Passed' ELSE 'Failed' END) AS Status, prefix_course.fullname AS course FROM prefix_grade_grades INNER JOIN prefix_grade_items ON prefix_grade_grades.itemid = prefix_grade_items.id INNER JOIN prefix_course ON prefix_grade_items.courseid = prefix_course.id

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Only need Failed Results
ResponsesInList.Text: Does adding this next line to where conditions work for you? AND ROUND(prefix_grade_grades.finalgrade, 0) < prefix_grade_items.gradepass Full query: SELECT prefix_user.firstname, prefix_user.lastname, prefix_user.email, prefix_grade_items.gradepass AS pointstopass, ROUND(prefix_grade_grades.finalgrade, 0) AS pointsobtained, ROUND(prefix_grade_grades.finalgrade / prefix_grade_items.grademax * 100, 0) AS finalgradepercent, (CASE WHEN ROUND(prefix_grade_grades.finalgrade, 0) >= prefix_grade_items.gradepass THEN 'Passed' ELSE 'Failed' END) AS Status, prefix_course.fullname AS course FROM prefix_grade_grades INNER JOIN prefix_grade_items ON prefix_grade_grades.itemid = prefix_grade_items.id INNER JOIN prefix_course ON prefix_grade_items.courseid = prefix_course.id INNER JOIN prefix_course_categories ON prefix_course.category = prefix_course_categories.id INNER JOIN prefix_user ON prefix_grade_grades.userid = prefix_user.id WHERE (prefix_grade_items.itemname IS NOT NULL) AND (prefix_grade_items.itemmodule = 'quiz' OR prefix_grade_items.itemmodule IS NULL) AND (prefix_grade_grades.timemodified IS NOT NULL) AND prefix_user.deleted = 0 AND prefix_user.suspended = 0 and (prefix_course.visible = 1) AND ROUND(prefix_grade_grades.finalgrade, 0) < prefix_grade_items.gradepass %%FILTER_COURSEENROLLEDSTUDENTS%%

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Only need Failed Results
ResponsesInList.Text: Perfect! Thank you! It makes perfect sense, now that I see it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Export report sql to xml
ResponsesInList.Text: Marco, That is correct. This xml file is an export of the report itself. Its purpose is for safekeeping a copy of the report as a file and/or to be able to share it or copy it to another Moodle installation. It does not contain any data. If you want the data provided by a particular report, you need to use one of the Export options on the Report menu, which are csv, json, ods or excel.

I have not done this in a long time, so I can't recommend any site in particular. I think also the Excel can export sheets to xml format for you. I don't use MS products, so perhaps someone else knows how to do that. For ods formats for LibreOffice, OpenOffice, there's a plugin exporter to do this: http://digitalimprint.com/misc/oooexport/

ResponsesInList.Title: Find private files of each user: alias/shortcuts to courses
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Community, we have some users who use "private files" in Moodle. Some of the files are placed in courses via alias/shortcut, some others as a copy. If users open their private files repository and click on a file they can see, in which courses the files are linked as alias/shortcut. As Moodle Admin I wan't to know which user has private files and in which courses the linked files are placed: list of all users (ID, Firstname, Lastname) who uses private files list of private files (filename, filepath in private file folder, filesize) list of courses (ID, shortname, lastname) where these files are linked as alias/shortcut PS: we have a database query which finds all private files of a user ```text Select u.firstname, u.lastname, u.username, ``` ```text concat('',u.id,'') as 'ID and link to user profile', ``` ```text DATE_FORMAT(FROM_UNIXTIME(u.lastlogin), '%e %b %Y') AS 'lastlogin', u.suspended AS 'active (0) or suspended (1) User', f.filename, f.filesize ``` ```text from prefix_files AS f ``` ```text JOIN prefix_user AS u ON u.id = f.userid ``` ```text where filearea = "private" ``` Mayb it es easy to customise this query, but I don't know how to find out the courses and files which are placed via alias/shortcut. Any ideas? thanks, br Anton

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Find private files of each user: alias/shortcuts to courses
ResponsesInList.Text: Anton,

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Find private files of each user: alias/shortcuts to courses
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Randy, thanks for your help. It concerns several tables: context , course_modules, user, course, files - so It was not easy to get the whole information, but following query will show me the correct information I want - maybe it's interesting for others: ```text select f.contextid, f.component, f.filearea, f.filename, concat('',f.userid,'') as 'ID and Link to Userprofile', u.firstname, u.lastname, f.filesize, f.mimetype, f.source, f.author, f.referencefileid, c.instanceid as 'ID from prefix_context', cm.id as 'ID from prefix_course_modules', concat('',cm.course,'') as kursid_and_link, co.fullname, co.shortname from prefix_files as f JOIN prefix_context AS c ON c.id = f.contextid JOIN prefix_course_modules as cm ON cm.id = c.instanceid JOIN prefix_user as u ON u.id = f.userid JOIN prefix_course as co ON co.id = cm.course where referencefileid != "" ``` thanks, br Anton

ResponsesInList.Title: Help with adding a cohort filter
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, A little new to configurable reports, and Im no sql expert. Thats only two strikes. Ive been creating many reports since I recently installed the plugin and using some of the many sql examples from moodle docs page. Now I want to add a cohort filter to many of my reports. I found documentation on how to do that, although Im still working on that... Anyways I also found this previous post here that appears to have the answer, but not the actual sql that solved the problem, and I cant figure out  how to incorporate the logic and where clause with this sql. In other words, the sql in that post worked for me (see below), but when talking about working in the logic for cohorts and adding a where clause is not working for me. Can anyone suggest the edit (and/or any additional steps needed) for this sql to add a cohort filter? SELECT DISTINCT u.lastname as "Last Name", u.firstname as "First Name", concat('',c.fullname,'') AS Course, case when ccom.timecompleted IS NULL then concat('', 'Not Complete','') when ccom.timecompleted IS NOT NULL then 'Completed' end as "Completion Status" FROM {user} AS u JOIN {course_completions} AS ccom ON u.id = ccom.userid JOIN {course} AS c ON c.id = ccom.course ORDER BY u.lastname, u.firstname,c.fullname

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Help with adding a cohort filter
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm not sure about the configurable reports part of it -- cohorts isn't one of the filters specfied in the documentation, but if you're able to enter the cohort name or id, the sql to select the above, but filtered on cohorts would be SELECT DISTINCT u.lastname as "Last Name", u.firstname as "First Name", concat(' ',c.fullname,' ') AS Course, case when ccom.timecompleted IS NULL then concat(' ', 'Not Complete',' ') when ccom.timecompleted IS NOT NULL then 'Completed' end as "Completion Status" FROM {user} AS u JOIN {course_completions} AS ccom ON u.id = ccom.userid JOIN {course} AS c ON c.id = ccom.course join {cohort_members} cm on cm.userid=u.id join {cohort} co on co.id=cm.cohortid ORDER BY u.lastname, u.firstname,c.fullname if you want to filter on cohort name then it would be where co.name= ... Note that in this case cohort membership is treated independently of the course; if you're using cohort enrolments, then you may want to factor that in, so for a cohort you only see the list of people and courses relevant to that cohort., rather than all courses for people in a particular cohort.

My Sum statement does not product an error, but it also does not produce any results. My SQL Query is off-here and there because when an active employee is moved to a new job position their cohort membership is removed. The filter current enrolments is not reading the adjusted cohort membership. The course participation's enrollments are correct, but my SQL Queries are always a little overstated here and there. Is there a way I can correct the issues I am having with this query? SELECT DISTINCT CONCAT(u.firstname, ' ', u.lastname) AS Name, COUNT(p.timeenrolled) as 'Assigned', COUNT(p.timecompleted) AS 'TotalCompletions', SUM(('TotalCompletions' / 'Assigned' )*100) As PercentComplete FROM prefix_course_completions AS p JOIN prefix_course AS c ON p.course = c.id AND c.visible = 1 JOIN prefix_user AS u ON p.userid = u.id AND u.deleted = 0 AND u.suspended = 0 %%FILTER_COURSES:id%% %%FILTER_COURSEENROLLEDSTUDENTS%% GROUP BY p.userid ORDER BY Name Kind Regards

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Summary Query - I am stymied by two issues.
ResponsesInList.Text: Shirley, For the SUM just use the actual columns in the calculation: p.timecompleted / p.timeenrolled. For the cohorts, is the user being re-enrolled again in the same course via another cohort? That is, unenrolled and then re-enrolled? And if so, then the user is probably taken out of this course completion table on unenroll and being added back again on the new enrol with its new dates.

ResponsesInList.Title: SQL help needed to incorporate filter into query
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm using this report as my starting point: ( https://docs.moodle.org/310/en/ad-hoc_contributed_reports#Site-Wide_Grade_Report_with_All_Items ), and the query works, but the filter I added in Moodle had no effect on the report.  From another forum, I learned that I need to edit the code to incorporate the filter into the query for it to have any effect.  I tried checking the documentation for this plugin to figure out what I need to add to the SQL code. I added these lines: WHERE 1=1 %%FILTER_SEARCHTEXT:u.username%% in the code below, but can't seem to get the syntax right.  Moodle keeps telling me that I have an error and need to check the manual that corresponds to my version of MariaDB , but I'm not sure where to find what to find my version information.  How do I find this information, and what am I doing wrong? SELECT u.firstname AS 'First' , u.lastname AS 'Last', CONCAT(u.firstname,' ',u.lastname) AS 'Display Name', u.username AS 'Username', c.fullname AS 'Course', CASE WHEN gi.itemtype = 'course' THEN ' Course Total' ELSE gi.itemname

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: SQL help needed to incorporate filter into query
ResponsesInList.Text: The FROM clause must immediately follow the SELECT clause, and it it must be immediately followed by the WHERE clause. You have two WHERE clauses, one stuck in the middle in the wrong place, and you can only have one, after the FROM. See: https://www.tutorialspoint.com/mysql/mysql-select-query.htm . You need to move the filter from the first WHERE clause to the second WHERE clause to create one single clause.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: SQL help needed to incorporate filter into query
ResponsesInList.Text: I missed the second WHERE clause. Thanks! This is the original report I got from the ad hoc page, and it works, even though the FROM clause is separated from the SELECT clause,so I guess I'm confused: SELECT u.firstname AS 'First' , u.lastname AS 'Last', u.firstname + ' ' + u.lastname AS 'Display Name', c.fullname AS 'Course', cc.name AS 'Category', CASE WHEN gi.itemtype = 'course' THEN c.fullname + ' Course Total' ELSE gi.itemname END AS 'Item Name', ROUND(gg.finalgrade,2) AS Grade, DATEADD(ss,gg.timemodified,'1970-01-01') AS TIME FROM prefix_course AS c JOIN prefix_context AS ctx ON c.id = ctx.instanceid JOIN prefix_role_assignments AS ra ON ra.contextid = ctx.id JOIN prefix_user AS u ON u.id = ra.userid JOIN prefix_grade_grades AS gg ON gg.userid = u.id JOIN prefix_grade_items AS gi ON gi.id = gg.itemid JOIN prefix_course_categories AS cc ON cc.id = c.category WHERE gi.courseid = c.id ORDER BY lastname Here is the code as I've edited it. It's mostly the same, but I cannot get Moodle to execute the filter: SELECT u.firstname AS 'First' , u.lastname AS 'Last', CONCAT(u.firstname,' ',u.lastname) AS 'Display Name', u.username AS 'Username', c.fullname AS 'Course', CASE WHEN gi.itemtype = 'course' THEN ' Course Total' ELSE gi.itemname END AS 'Item Name', ROUND(gg.finalgrade,2) AS Grade, FROM_UNIXTIME(gg.timemodified) AS Time FROM prefix_course AS c JOIN prefix_context AS ctx ON c.id = ctx.instanceid JOIN prefix_role_assignments AS ra ON ra.contextid = ctx.id JOIN prefix_user AS u ON u.id = ra.userid JOIN prefix_grade_grades AS gg ON gg.userid = u.id JOIN prefix_grade_items AS gi ON gi.id = gg.itemid JOIN prefix_course_categories AS cc ON cc.id = c.category WHERE gi.courseid = c.id %%FILTER_SEARCHTEXT:u.username%% ORDER BY lastname

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: SQL help needed to incorporate filter into query
ResponsesInList.Text: Stephanie, Try this for your filter: %%FILTER_SEARCHTEXT:u.username:~%% There's a squiggly ~ at the end before the second %% - this is the indicator to the filter what to do. Also, your ORDER BY should have a u.lastname with the u. alias, otherwise it won't know what table you mean.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: SQL help needed to incorporate filter into query
ResponsesInList.Text: Randy, Thanks. I tried what you suggested, but Moodle's still ignoring the filter. Stephanie

ResponsesInList.Title: Only System administrator role can see Configurable Reports block
ResponsesInList.Text: I need to allow a specific user to see the Configurable Reports block and the reports in it.  Up to this point, only I as the system administrator have had need to view this block and the reports in it.  I created an "Administrator" role that is a copy of the non-editing teacher role because I don't want this user to be editing or deleting things, but I made it a system-level role.  I then assigned this person to that role. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Only System administrator role can see Configurable Reports block
ResponsesInList.Text: Are you trying to make this report visible on the user's dashboard . I don't know how to do that but it might be easier: - to create a course 'Reports and stuff' - to enrol you admin user there as a student - to add the configurable report block here, and create the reports you need - At the report level, to give permission at least to your user to see it (check the permission tab) For mysterious reasons you have to indicate something in the 'condition' field; I put 'c1 or c1' Hoe this helps, Th

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Only System administrator role can see Configurable Reports block
ResponsesInList.Text: Stephanie "I temporarily assigned this user the manager role, which is inherently a system role and appears should be able to see the block, but this user still can't see the block." Yes, this is so. Did the user in the Manager role actually add the block to their Dashboard ? It will not just show up as it does for the site admin. The user will need to Customize their Dashboard and use Add block to get it to show up. You suspect correctly that basing your role on the non-editing teacher is probably interfering. I find that the cleanest way of doing this is the following: Create a new role called something like Config Report user Rule archetype: None Context type: System Set these three permissions in the section Block: Configurable Reports Add a new configurable reports blockblock/configurable_reports:addinstance = Allow Add a new configurable reports block to MY HOME pageblock/configurable_reports:myaddinstance = Allow View reportsblock/configurable_reports:viewreports = Allow Save it and then add the user to this role in Assign system roles. If you only want the user to be able to add the block to their own Dashboard, and not to courses, then leave out the first permission. If at some point you want all users to run reports, you could add these particular permissions to the Authenticated user role and add the Block to the Default dashboard if you wanted to. But for a limited number of users or for testing things out, I prefer this method as it is safer. You still control which reports show up for whom using the Permissions tab on each specific report (about which, see https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=411546#p1659798 ) Randy

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Configurable Reports by User Group
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi Richard, I recently needed the ability to limit reports to only show members that were in the same group as the user running the report and came across your post. Using the suggestion from Emma, I created the following SQL report. In my case I was just looking for course completion, but it shouldn't be too hard to change this to pulling grades instead. I also made use of the Configurable Reports Filter capability. Hope the following helps you get what you need. I don't know how optimized my approach is, but I am working with just a small set of users on the system. 
```text
SELECT DISTINCT
course.fullname course,
CONCAT(user.firstname, ' ', user.lastname) AS 'Name',
user.email as 'Email',
user.city as 'City',
user.department as 'Department',
CASE
WHEN completions.timecompleted IS NOT NULL THEN ( FROM_UNIXTIME(completions.timecompleted, '%m-%d-%Y'))
ELSE '-Not Yet Completed-'
END AS 'Completion'



FROM prefix_course_completions AS completions
INNER JOIN prefix_course AS course ON completions.course = course.id AND course.visible = 1
INNER JOIN prefix_context AS cx ON course.id = cx.instanceid AND cx.contextlevel = '50'
INNER JOIN prefix_user AS user ON completions.userid = user.id AND user.deleted = 0 AND user.suspended = 0



INNER JOIN (SELECT vm.userid, vm.groupid, vg.id, vg.courseid, vg.name FROM prefix_groups_members AS vm
			INNER JOIN prefix_groups AS vg ON vg.id=vm.groupid
			INNER JOIN prefix_course AS c2 ON c2.id = vg.courseid
			WHERE vm.userid=%%USERID%%) AS groups ON groups.courseid = course.id



INNER JOIN prefix_groups_members AS members ON groups.id = members.groupid 
WHERE members.userid = user.id AND members.userid  %%USERID%% 
%%FILTER_COURSES:course.id%% 
%%FILTER_USERS:user.department%%



ORDER BY course
```

ResponsesInList.Text: Emma and Ron thank you for your solutions. I will see if I can get this to work for me and my situation.

),'%Y-%m-%d')  


AS completed

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: User course completion status always "Not yet started"
ResponsesInList.Text: SELECT CONCAT(u.firstname, ' ', u.lastname) AS Student, c.fullname AS 'Course Name', ##IF (cc.timecompleted=0,"",DATE_FORMAT(FROM_UNIXTIME(cc.timecompleted), '%M %e %Y')) AS 'Date Completed', IF ((cc.timecompleted=0 OR cc.timecompleted IS NULL), IF(cc.timestarted=0,"Not started","Not complete"), "Complete") AS Status

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: User course completion status always "Not yet started"
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Shirley, Thank you for the quick replay and your code. Unfortunately, it is only returning those learners that have completed the course. I also need to the status of all students that are enrolled. What seems to be happening with both the SQL I used and yours that for those students that have not completed there is not an entry in the course_completions table and therefore are not being returned. I am not familiar enough with SQL to know how to write this such that what is returned is not dependent on having an entry in course completions. Kind regards

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: User course completion status always "Not yet started"
ResponsesInList.Text: Sorry, It did not read carefully enough. You can try the SQL below, which was borrowed from much smarter people who contributed to the Ad-hoc contribution report list. https://docs.moodle.org/310/en/ad-hoc_contributed_reports This might be more what you are looking for, but for me it churns a lot of records. I normally change the WHERE state to be WHERE (c.id = X) and (c.visible = 1) to limit the report to just the specific course I need. SELECT course.fullname course, CONCAT(user.firstname, ' ', user.lastname) AS 'Name', FROM_UNIXTIME(completions.timeenrolled, '%m-%d-%Y') AS 'DateEnrolled', FROM_UNIXTIME(completions.timecompleted, '%m-%d-%Y') AS 'DateCompleted', CASE WHEN completions.timecompleted IS NOT NULL THEN ( FROM_UNIXTIME(completions.timecompleted, '%m-%d-%Y')) ELSE '-Not Yet Completed-' END AS 'Completion' FROM prefix_course_completions AS completions JOIN prefix_course AS course ON completions.course = course.id JOIN prefix_user AS user ON completions.userid = user.id AND user.deleted = 0 AND user.suspended = 0 WHERE (course.visible = 1) ORDER BY Completion %%FILTER_COURSEENROLLEDSTUDENTS%% Kind Regards

ResponsesInList.Title: Add fields to this activity completion report
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, I have moodle v.3.6.2. I copied this SQL script below, I wanted to see the activity completion across all my courses. I would like to change a few of the fields, but I don't know how to change it: Change the first field 'Username' field to 'Institution' Remove 'Activity Type' and 'Activity Completion Type' field Add user first name, last name and email field. Here is the code: SELECT u.username AS 'User', c.fullname AS 'Course', m.name AS Activitytype, CASE WHEN cm.module = 1 THEN (SELECT a1.name FROM prefix_assign a1            WHERE a1.id = cm.instance) WHEN cm.module = 2 THEN (SELECT a2.name FROM prefix_assignment a2    WHERE a2.id = cm.instance) WHEN cm.module = 3 THEN (SELECT a3.name FROM prefix_book a3               WHERE a3.id = cm.instance) WHEN cm.module = 4 THEN (SELECT a4.name FROM prefix_chat a4                WHERE a4.id = cm.instance) WHEN cm.module = 5 THEN (SELECT a5.name FROM prefix_choice a5            WHERE a5.id = cm.instance) WHEN cm.module = 6 THEN (SELECT a6.name FROM prefix_data a6                WHERE a6.id = cm.instance)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Add fields to this activity completion report
ResponsesInList.Text: Kathryn, To do 2), remove a field, you can either put a pound sign # in front of the lines to comment them or, or you can simply delete them. Each column of the report is separated by a comma in the SELECT statement. So put a # in front of the start of the column logic you wish to remove. If you want to add other fields related to users, then you need to know the names of those fields, which are: u.firstname, u.lastname, u.email, u.institution. The names of the user fields here are the very same ones used in other places such as the user upload field. They are standard names. You can add those in any place you want between the word SELECT and the keyword FROM - those are define the columns in the order you want. Just make sure there is a comma between each one. So, u.username, u.firstname, u.lastname, u.email, u.company, u.institution is the same as u.lastname, u.firstname, u.institution, u.company, u.email, u.username but the order is different. You can order them any way you wish, include or exclude the ones you wish. You will find many examples of these over in the Ad-hoc reports page. Good luck & watch your commas... Randy

ResponsesInList.Title: Course Recomplete Query-Needs Improvement
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, I have a simple query to have an understanding of when the Course Recomplete plugin has updated (deleted) a student's current course completion to trigger retraining. The query below works in a limited way, Row 6 returns the values or 0 (zero) or 1 because of the IS Null statement instead of the date I was attempting to retrieve. Any assistance would be appreciated. Kind Regards. SELECT course.fullname course, CONCAT(user.firstname, ' ', user.lastname) AS 'Name', FROM_UNIXTIME(completions.timeenrolled, '%m-%d-%Y') AS 'DateEnrolled', FROM_UNIXTIME(completions.timecompleted, '%m-%d-%Y') AS 'DateCompleted', FROM_UNIXTIME(completions.timecompleted, '%m-%d-%Y') IS NULL AS 'Notified' FROM prefix_course_completions AS completions JOIN prefix_course AS course ON completions.course = course.id JOIN prefix_user AS user ON completions.userid = user.id AND user.deleted = 0 AND user.suspended = 0 WHERE (course.id = 90) and (course.visible = 1) ORDER BY DateCompleted ##%%course.fullname%% %%FILTER_COURSEENROLLEDSTUDENTS%%

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course Recomplete Query-Needs Improvement
ResponsesInList.Text: Shirley,

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course Recomplete Query-Needs Improvement
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Randy, Thank you so very much for sharing your knowledge and experience with SQL . Yes the plugin, wipes out the grade and completion entirely and no graceful way for an administrator to know which/when the students need to recomplete the course. I have been checking the event logs for the courses with the recompletion rule, but I needed to find a better, long-term solution. Kind Regards, Shirley

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course Recomplete Query-Needs Improvement
ResponsesInList.Text: Ah yes, then the obvious problem is that when the timecompleted field is NULL that can mean the user is working on the course for the first time as well as a subsequent time: this field is always NULL until the user actually completes the course and gets a timestamp. So you don't actually know what the NULL means: are they are working on the course the first time or are they completed once and this is then a subsequent attempt at the course is about to start off. NULL really means is "not complete on the current attempt (but I can't tell you which attempt that is!)." Does the plugin itself actually track the user attempts elsewhere? Does it know which attempt at the course this is for the user, second, third, twentieth? Does it save past completion dates somewhere at all before wiping them out? Does it also set to NULL the previous timeenrolled and timestarted when a new attempt is starting up again? (It should, otherwise your progress stats will be way off.) Or is it removing the database row from the previous attempts altogether and then adding a new row for this particular course and user (since there can only be one row in the table for the same user/course combination.)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course Recomplete Query-Needs Improvement
ResponsesInList.Text: These are all very good questions! You understand my query issue completely, there is no way to discern the never completed from the retraining need. Up until recently, the courses with the recompletion condition had a very small training audience, that was easy to find the "reset" in the course events logs. Now, that we turned on the recomplete condition for courses with large enrollments, and students with a wide range of start dates, it is a little challenging without a query. So far, I have never needed to ventured into the table data. However, the plugin does have the option to "Archive completion data." I always select the option, so the data row should be preserved in the tables. Additionally, the "attempts" can be viewed on the student's quiz history and individual student quiz attempts page, which verifies the attempt is retrained. Also, since we use learning plans and competencies, we are able to view each time the competency is awarded. Your last statement, makes me wonder how the "Archive" data is being stored if only one row can be for the same user/course combination?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course Recomplete Query-Needs Improvement
ResponsesInList.Text: I just reviewed all of the plug-in documentation and various discussion. The following information is cleared from the course during recompletion: •All activity grades cleared (and saved to standard grade history tables.) •All activity completion and course completion flags removed. (with the option to archive this information) I guess I need to know if the archive option preserve a date/time stamp when the "Course completion flag is removed"?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course Recomplete Query-Needs Improvement
ResponsesInList.Text: Right. Really, for the big picture, it depends on how much you need to save that older completion and other information. Since it is removing a lot of data so the user can retake the course, then as long as you have a copy of that data you need - grades, completion dates, etc. - then you are good. You can extract that in reports. Or maybe you need all the student data via a backup for audit compliance of some sort. Regarding the report, where you can't be sure if a NULL completion means the user is doing the course for the first time or second/subsequent time. One quick and dirty way to work around this would be to show the dates. You could probably figure out from the dates in the timeenrolled and timestarted columns whether this is a current "re-attempt" or an old one. So, for instance, if you are doing a re-enrollment once a year for certification type re-compliance, it may be clear the user is re-taking it. Try just adding those dates to the columns and see if that is of any real help. Another avenue to look at is exactly what you say: is the plugin's archive option saving something somewhere that tells you for sure that the user has done the course before? Does it do this each time they redo the course? Does that have date and time stamps? You can try this experiment in a test course: do the re-enrollment with the archive off once and then again with it on for some test users, and then look in the database to see what it does. The archive data should be somewhere, and it won't be in the course_completion table, but in some table the plugin has for its own (probably/hopefully .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course Recomplete Query-Needs Improvement
ResponsesInList.Text: Also, you can always find through the log how many times a user actually was enrolled in the same course. So, wherever all the user data may be archived off to (or not), the fact of the enrollment over time is still logged with the role_assign event.

ResponsesInList.Title: How can I create a SQL query that only shows courses that have moved into a particular category within the current month?
ResponsesInList.Text:
I have a query that shows the course creation date and the category they're in, but I can't see anything in mdl_logstore_standard_log, mdl_course or mdl_course_categories that I can use to create filter on when they were moved. When moving the course to another category, it creates this entry in the logstore_standard_log table: The query I'm running is a simple one: 
```text
select cat.name, c.* from mdl_course c


   join mdl_course_categories cat on cat.id = c.category


      and cat.path = '/15/' or cat.path like '/15/%'


order by 


   cat.name asc,


   c.fullname asc
```
 I want this query only to show courses that were moved into this categoryid within the current month. I know I can filter the log table on the timemodified column on each log entry (i.e. and date_format(from_unixtime(c.timemodified), '%Y-%m') = date_format(now(), '%Y-%m')) to show the courses that have been edited within the current month, but this doesn't capture the courses moving between categories. Does anyone have a solution for this they're willing to share? Much appreciated in advance!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How can I create a SQL query that only shows courses that have moved into a particular category within the current month?
ResponsesInList.Text: Matthew, The log event that this creates is one where the eventname is "\core\event\course_updated" and the action is "updated" as well. The target of course is "course". You can filter on that in your code.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Documentation for Report Conditions
ResponsesInList.Text: Stephanie, This is a hard question to answer since there is no documentation, but I have figured it out with a little help from the code. The value to put for time and date fields such as current login, last login, etc is the original Unix timestamp. For example, Sep 30, 2020 at midnight is 91715259481 and if you create a condition such as currentlogin > 91715259481 then it will show you only those current logins after that date and time as expected. If you are familiar with Unix time stamps, that will make sense. If not you can use this online tool https://www.timestampconvert.com/ to convert real dates to the magic timestamp you need. And of course, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unix_time will help. I am sure that Juan had planned one day to add some human readable options here, but the basic math seems to work as long as you use the timestamp itself. Try that out for now and see if that works for you. Randy

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Documentation for Report Conditions
ResponsesInList.Text: Randy, Thank you!  That did it.  I knew I was missing something, and the Unix time stamp was it. Stephanie

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Documentation for Report Conditions
ResponsesInList.Text: Now we all know! I would not have guessed that, but that's how it works. Glad that solves your issue. Of course, in SQL you have a lot more options, esp. if you need relative dates... Randy

ResponsesInList.Title: Compatibility with IOMAD
ResponsesInList.Text: Is there any way to make the Configurable Reports plugin compatible with IOMAD? Ideally, we want to be able to build reports whose data is restricted to that of the company which the report is being viewed on. I thought we could maybe achieve this with FILTER_VAR, but we don't want company administrators to be able to see the data of another company by simply changing the id of the filter var in the URL . I know that this isn't usually the place for IOMAD questions, but it's hard to get answers on the IOMAD github repo, and this is more to do with how we can extend the functionality of the configurable reports block (or work with it's existing functionality) to achieve what we want, rather than a query with IOMAD itself. I hope someone can help - the plugin seems exactly what we want except for this small but vital issue! Many thanks

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Compatibility with IOMAD
ResponsesInList.Text: Mark, Yes, there is. I do lots of Iomad reports and I just always add logic to a report that limits the results to the user's company. For instance: SELECT u.username, c.name FROM prefix_user u JOIN prefix_company_users cu ON cu.userid = u.id JOIN prefix_company c ON c.id = cu.companyid WHERE u.id = %%USERID%% will show a user only the users in their company with its name. The least code you would need assuming the user table is already used would be: JOIN prefix_company_users cu ON cu.userid = u.id

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Compatibility with IOMAD
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks so much Randy, that's exactly what I was looking for! My SQL skills are not the best so I really appreciate the help

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Compatibility with IOMAD
ResponsesInList.Text: Most welcome. If you have any questions on it, just post here and I will try to follow up. The database structures Iomad adds to Moodle are very clear and well designed. Those two tables handle all the company data and you can get almost all you need for reporting from just those two using variations on the code above. Good luck.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Compatibility with IOMAD
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Randy, Thanks again for your help. I had a problem with your query however - the result was just one user; the current user. Correct me if I'm wrong (I probably am) but your minimal extra code example: JOIN prefix_company_users cu ON cu.userid = u.id WHERE u.id = %%USERID%% ...will always only return the current user, just with extra data from the company users table available to be SELECTed? I changed the WHERE clause to the following: WHERE c.id = (SELECT companyid FROM prefix_company_users WHERE userid = %%USERID%%) ..and that seemed to give me the results I wanted. I'm not convinced that that is the correct way to do things though - I'd rather do it without a subquery as you did. Mark

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Compatibility with IOMAD
ResponsesInList.Text: My code is just a snippet to show you how to use the tables for any sort of restriction to a company. Basically any way you do it will work as long as you are limited the output to the same company that the user is a member of. So, a subquery is fine as long as that is getting what the main query is suppose to do.

ResponsesInList.Title: Odp: Re: Compatibility with IOMAD
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Randy! Do you know how to use in that SQL some global variable of current company? I want to prepare the same report for each of my tenants and I don't want to set fixed id in sql query. It would be awesome if it was possible to set the current company. Thanks in advance.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Odp: Re: Compatibility with IOMAD
ResponsesInList.Text: Michal, There is no variable such as %%COMPANY%% since the plugin is written for standard Moodle and not for Iomad. But you don't need it anyway. All you need to do is make sure in your WHERE clause that all the users in the report belong to in the same company as the user running the report. In fact, if you have turned on the Iomad syncing of company to the standard user profile institution field, you can use that. Actually, I just posted some code on how to do exactly that for someone else a few days ago, here: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=410885#p1657522 . That limits the report to showing only users with the same institution as the user running the report. Randy

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: SQL query with quiz and configurable reports
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes, I do. I think instead you can do two changes: 1) a GROUP BY on Questionusageid instead of the attempt. It seems this is the same for all the responses in one set/attempt. And 2) you will need to change those CASE statements into sub-select statements, one per slot, otherwise they end up on separate lines instead of one line. At least, that is how I have gotten it to work for me. Attached is a Config Reports XML file that you can import into your Config Reports in the "Import report" area at the bottom of the Manage reports page. After you do that, take a look at the code. You will see that I have changed the slots into subselect statements, one per slot. You can add more slots as you will probably need and obviously edit their names for the columns you need (Nombre de alumno, etc.).  These will show up all on the same line now in the report. Also, you will need to change the course and quiz names in the WHERE statement to what you need. See the attached image of the output, which has one line per each set of responses with all the slots on one line. Let me know if this works for you. I tested this in 3.8 but it should work in 3.9 as well. -- Randy

r on ra.roleid = r.id ``` ```text         and r.shortname = 'student' -- replace with the role required to report on. ``` ```text     left join mdl_groups g on c.id = g.courseid - a course may not have any groups ``` ```text     left join mdl_groups_members members on g.id = members.groupid -- there may be no members in a group ``` ```text     join mdl_course_categories course_cat on course_cat.id = c.category ``` ```text group by members.groupid ``` ```text order by ``` ```text     c.id asc, ``` ```text     g.name asc ``` Your help is greatly appreciated

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Issue with FILTER_COURSE

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: filter option... help
ResponsesInList.Text:
You need to add the filter to your SQL. For the courses filter it would look like this: 
```text
%%FILTER_COURSES:c.id%%
```
 If you add it after your WHERE statement before your ORDER BY that should do it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ri: Re: filter option... help
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hey David, I don't know that there is a way in the standard plugin to do what you're asking. However, if you're ok with a text field instead of a dropdown, you could search against the users by adding a "search text" filter and then adding the following to your report below the last filter entry: 
```text
%%FILTER_SEARCHTEXT:CONCAT(u.firstname, ' ', u.lastname):~%%
```

ResponsesInList.Title: Odp: Re: Letter Grade Report
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Ben, I am trying to adapt your code to my report. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Odp: Re: Letter Grade Report
ResponsesInList.Text: This version has a column for what the grade letter would be using the site default grade scale. You can tell the site default is used when the overridden column is null. -Ben ------ select c.id courseid, c.fullname course, u.id userid, concat(u.lastname, ', ', u.firstname) user, #percent rounded to 2 decimal places round(g.finalgrade,2) percent, #letter grade, uses any custom letters for the course (SELECT l.letter FROM mdl_grade_letters l join mdl_context x on l.contextid = x.id WHERE x.contextlevel = 50 and x.instanceid in (c.id, 0) and l.lowerboundary <= g.finalgrade ORDER BY x.id desc, lowerboundary desc limit 1) overridden_grade_scale, (SELECT l.letter FROM mdl_grade_letters l WHERE l.contextid = 1 and l.lowerboundary <= g.finalgrade ORDER BY l.lowerboundary desc limit 1) default_grade_scale, #this is the grade feedback from the gradebook, you could see this in SingleView g.feedback comments from mdl_user AS u join mdl_grade_grades g on g.userid = u.id join mdl_grade_items gi on gi.id = g.itemid JOIN mdl_course c on c.id = gi.courseid #Join relationship for student role in the course JOIN mdl_enrol AS en ON en.courseid = c.id JOIN mdl_user_enrolments AS ue ON ue.enrolid = en.id and ue.userid = u.id JOIN mdl_context AS ctx ON c.id = ctx.instanceid JOIN mdl_role_assignments AS ra ON ra.contextid = ctx.id and ra.userid = u.id JOIN mdl_role r on ra.roleid = r.id where gi.itemtype = 'course' #filter required for student role AND r.shortname = 'student' #specific userid and u.id = 86 #specific courseid and gi.courseid = 815

ResponsesInList.Title: Enrolment method count during last 7 days
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, I'm a first-time poster so apologies if I've posted in the wrong place or this questions has been asked before (I've had a look but couldn't find anything) I would like to write an SQL report that counts the number of enrolment methods by course. What I have so far is: SELECT c.fullname AS 'Course', e.enrol AS 'Method', Count(e.enrol) AS 'Count' FROM {user_enrolments} AS ue JOIN {enrol} AS e ON e.id = ue.enrolid JOIN {course} AS c ON c.id = e.courseid GROUP BY c.fullname, e.enrol However I would like the count to be for course enrolments started within the last 7 days. Could anyone please give me a little help? I'd really appreciate it Thanks Stuart

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Enrolment method count during last 7 days
ResponsesInList.Text: Stuart, In the user_enrolments table there are two columns, timecreated and timemodified. The created one is when the enrollment was first made (by whatever method). If it gets changed or edited after that for some reason, then the modified date holds that. You can use either one of those dates and add a WHERE clause to check that those dates are within the last seven days. There's a similar snippet of code you can use in this query https://docs.moodle.org/38/en/ad-hoc_contributed_reports#Users_loggedin_within_the_last_7_days over in the query repository page.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Enrolment method count during last 7 days
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Randy, thats a great help! Really appreciate it!

ResponsesInList.Title: Configurable report showing all ACTIVE enrolments who have not logged in for the past 60+days
ResponsesInList.Text:
Howdy Moodle Community My boss has asked me to build a c onfigurable
report showing all ACTIVE enrolments who have not logged in for the past
60+days site wide. We are running Moodle 3.5 and I’ve installed the configurable block report and I’ve added
the report columns I require but have no idea on the exact conditions or filters need to be added to only see ACTIVE enrolments who have not logged into our site for the past 60+days. Can anyone step me through setting up the conditions or filters so I only see ACTIVE enrolments with no activity for the past 60+days? I know that this is probably considered basic Moodle knowledge but I'm admin level with no technical experience. Thanks in advance! Kym

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Configurable report showing all ACTIVE enrolments who have not logged in for the past 60+days
ResponsesInList.Text:
Kym, The status field in the mdl_user_enrolments table tells you the status of the the user's enrolment in the course, where 0 = active and 1 = suspended. So, something like 
```text
WHERE ue.status = 0
```
 checks for this. It may be different for different courses, of course. So what your boss thinks is "an active user" may vary from course to course. If you mean that a user account as a whole is active or not, that is shown in the mdl_user table in the suspended column, where 1 = true and 0 = false, meaning active. So active users will have a 0 there. 
```text
WHERE u.suspended = 0
```
 means all active users, leaving out suspended accounts.

where lsl.action = 'loggedin'

group by from_unixtime(lsl.timecreated,"%D %M %Y")


order by lsl.timecreated desc

ResponsesInList.Title: List of all students with groups, enrolment, and completion information
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all. I've run into a challenge due to my limited knowledge of SQL queries. I'm trying to generate a custom report within each course that gives us a list of users including the group they belong to, how they enrolled, and when they completed. I've been getting close, except that the report only gives me the users who belong to a group, but it excludes users who do not belong to any groups. How can I tweak my query to include all users, whether they belong to a group or not? I'd ideally like the query to return a full list of all active students, and if the don;t belong to a group, have the group field left blank or return "No Groups" like the participant page in Moodle does. We're running Moodle 3.5 Here's the query I'm running: SELECT c.shortname AS Course, g.name AS Groupname, u.firstname, u.lastname, er.enrol AS enrolmethod, FROM_UNIXTIME(ue.timecreated) AS Enroldate, FROM_UNIXTIME(cc.timecompleted) AS Finishdate FROM prefix_course AS c JOIN prefix_groups AS g ON g.courseid = c.id JOIN prefix_groups_members AS m ON g.id = m.groupid JOIN prefix_user AS u ON  m.userid = u.id JOIN prefix_enrol AS er ON er.courseid = c.id JOIN prefix_user_enrolments AS ue ON ue.enrolid = er.id AND ue.userid = u.id JOIN prefix_course_completions AS cc ON cc.course = c.id AND cc.userid = u.id WHERE c.id = %%COURSEID%%

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: List of all students with groups, enrolment, and completion information
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Dennis, I'm in a similar boat. Did you resolve your issue? If so, please share - this is driving me crazy!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: List of all students with groups, enrolment, and completion information
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Dennis and Matthew. I recommend you to start simplifying our challenge. Try to list only each student and group. And for those students not inside any group, you could use LEFT|RIGTH OUTER JOIN . Let's start understanding OUTER queries: https://www.techonthenet.com/mysql/joins.php I think that is the first key step for your requirements... Good luck!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: List of all students with groups, enrolment, and completion information
ResponsesInList.Text: -- OUTER JOIN WAY select grp.gName, u.* from (select c.id as cid, m.id as mid, g.name as gName FROM mdl_course AS c JOIN mdl_groups AS g ON g.courseid = c.id JOIN mdl_groups_members AS m ON g.id = m.groupid WHERE c.id = %%COURSEID%%) grp RIGHT OUTER JOIN mdl_user AS u ON grp.mid = u.id

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: List of all students with groups, enrolment, and completion information
ResponsesInList.Text: Miguel is pointing you in the right direction with good advice on making a simple query first just on the groups. The issue is that JOIN to the Groups tables is an INNER JOIN, and therefore it excludes any data that in not in those tables. Therefore it leaves out all users who belong to no Group since there will not be an entry for them in the Groups Members table (for that one course, that is.) A LEFT join instead of an INNER is probably the solution here.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: List of all students with groups, enrolment, and completion information
ResponsesInList.Text:
I managed to successfully write the report that returns the number of users in groups based on their role, but I can't find a way to also include those not in groups. I assume I have to use a subquery that uses the NOT IN function? 
```text
select


    cat.name category,


    c.fullname course,


    g.name "group",


    count(distinct gm.userid) groupmembertotal,


    sum(case when ra.roleid = 5 then 1 else 0 end) groupstudentcount, -- mdl_role.id 5 = student role


    sum(case when ra.roleid = 9 then 1 else 0 end) groupspnetcount -- mdl_role.id 9 = spnet custom role


from mdl_course_categories cat


    join mdl_course c on c.category = cat.id


    join mdl_context ct on ct.instanceid = c.id


        and ct.contextlevel = 50


    join mdl_role_assignments ra on ra.contextid = ct.id


    join mdl_groups g on g.courseid = c.id


    join mdl_groups_members gm on gm.groupid = g.id


        and gm.userid = ra.userid


group by ra.contextid, c.fullname, g.name
```
 Ideally, you should be joining ra.roleid to mdl_role so you can pull the role information from mdl_role.shortname instead of ra.roleid (especially if you are rolling this out over different Moodle LMSs that may have different mdl_role.ids), but this works for single-instance Moodle LMSs.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Installation steps for Configurable Reports on moodle 3.7
ResponsesInList.Text: You only need to fill in those DB HOST, DB NAME, etc. fields if you are connecting to an external database . If you only have one database - your main Moodle database - then leave them blank. Then add the Configurable Reports block to your Moodle front page and you'll be ready to start creating reports. So leave those defaults in your screenshots and you should be able to start creating reports with the defaults.

ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you Luis

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Installation steps for Configurable Reports on moodle 3.7
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Luis, would you happen to know how i could access a custom field which i created on moodle registration page on SQL report? Many Thanks

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Installation steps for Configurable Reports on moodle 3.7
ResponsesInList.Text:
A bit late... but something like this maybe??? Your custom fields are stored in the mdl_user_info_data table, so join that table to the mdl_user table (and any other tables you want). Example: 
```text
SELECT


    u.username,


    u.lastname,


    uid.data AS yourcustomfield


FROM mdl_user u


INNER JOIN mdl_user_info_data uid ON u.id = uid.userid


WHERE uid.fieldid = 1     -- Use 1 if this is the first custom field you've created


AND uid.data LIKE N'something'
```

ResponsesInList.Title: Send Automatic Report (logs in a CSV file) of a specific user once logged in on a specific date
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Moodlers, I would like to do the following: Once a specific user (lets say username 712231) logged in on a specific date, I want to automatically send a report (containing the log history, in a CSV file, of username 712231 at that specific date) in an email Is it possible to do it ? and if it is possible could you help me writing this function of procedure Best regards.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Send Automatic Report (logs in a CSV file) of a specific user once logged in on a specific date
ResponsesInList.Text: I don't think Configurable Reports can do that. You would have to write code to extend the Configurable Reports functionality - or write a separate plugin entirely. It would have to listen for those user login events that would trigger the email. Then it would have to generate the .csv file and attach it to an email. You don't say who the emails must be sent to, so that needs further clarification too. What log history do you want to include? Moodle logs can get pretty large! So, in addition, it would probably be wise to build in some logic that checks the size of the .csv files and restricts them to some maximum size, to prevent trying to send really large .csv file attachments via email that could "crash" your email server or exceed any "maximum attachment file size" limitations that your email service may impose. So what you need seems more like a custom plugin. Configurable Reports wasn't really designed to do all that.

ResponsesInList.Title: Configurable Reports: White Screen of... Nada?
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi Moodle mates, I am having trouble with Configurable Reports. Maybe I have just not installed it correctly? Maybe my LMS is botched? Maybe it was just Monday; whatever the case, I could use a hand with understanding why my LMS goes to a white screen when I attempt to configure  a report. Sometimes it does this even before I click Update or Add, etc. I just choose an option, and bam, white screen of...nada. Here is my workflow for someone to try and repeat: I choose
to create a new Users Report. I choose 10 for Pagination, the Javascript ordering tick, and export to csv. On the
next page, I choose User statistics, then "logins in the platform". I
name the column Col001, then hit Add. White screen of death. Another scenario is the same as above but on the
next page choose only "User course completion status". The screen
immediately jumps to the white blank before I can even hit Update. Please help.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Configurable Reports: White Screen of... Nada?
ResponsesInList.Text: Is this a new problem or has this always been a problem on your Moodle site? Did you recently upgrade Moodle or the Configurable Reports plugin? If you recently did an upgrade was the Configurable Report working before the upgrade? Moodle and PHP have debugging options that enable Moodle to display extra information when a problem like this occurs and record the problem details in a log file. When the debugging options are not enabled (they aren't by default) Moodle just displays that "white screen" (because it was not able to recover from the error). Have a look at https://docs.moodle.org/38/en/Debugging#Enabling_debugging and then enable the Debugging options in Moodle. Then try to reproduce the problem again in Moodle so that details of the problem can be displayed. You should then see an error message in Moodle (or in the PHP log file) when the problem is triggered again. Share those error details here so we can try to decode it. What version of Moodle and PHP are you using?
